SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Begger and Hostes, Christophero Sly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Begger.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile pheeze you infaith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: A paire of ſtockes you rogue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: Y'are a baggage, the Slies are no Rogues. Looke in the Chronicles, we came in with Richard Conqueror: therefore Pau-cas pallabris, let the world ſlide: Seſſa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: You will not pay for the glaſſes you haue burst?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: No, not a deniere: go by S[aint]. Ieronimie, goe to thy cold bed, and warme thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: I know my remedie, I must go fetch the Head-borough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: Third, or fourth, or fift Borough, Ile answere him by Law. Ile not budge an inch boy: Let him come, and kindly.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Winde hornes. Enter a Lord from hunting, with his traine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.
SPEECH.LINE: Huntsman I charge thee, tender wel my hounds,
Brach Meriman, the poore Curre is imbost,
And couple Clowder with the deepe-mouth’d brach,
Saw'st thou not boy how Siluer made it good
At the hedge corner, in the couldest fault,
I would not loose the dogge for twentie pound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunts.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Belman is as good as he my Lord,
He cried vpon it at the meerest loſſe,
And twice to day pick’d out the dullest ſent,
Trust me, I take him for the better dogge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art a Foole, if Eccho were as fleete,
I would esteeme him worth a dozen ſuch:
But ſup them well, and looke vnto them all,
To morrow I intend to hunt againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunts.
SPEECH.LINE: I will my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: What's heere? One dead, or drunke? See doth he breath?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Hun.
SPEECH.LINE: He breath's my Lord. Were he not warm’d with Ale, this were a bed but cold to ſleep ſo ſoundly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh monstrous beast, how like a ſwine he lyes.
Grim death, how foule and loathsome is thine image:
Sirs, I will practise on this drunken man.
What thinke you, if he were conuey’d to bed,
Wrap’d in ſweet cloathes: Rings put vpon his fingers:
A mo’t delicious banquet by his bed,
And braue attendants neere him when he wakes,
Would not the begger then forget himselfe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Hun.
SPEECH.LINE: Beleeue me Lord, I thinke he cannot choose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.H.
SPEECH.LINE: It would ſeem ſtrange vnto him when he wak’d

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen as a flatt'ring dreame, or worthles fancie.
Then take him vp, and manage well the iest:
Carrie him gently to my fairest Chamber,
And hang it round with all my wanton pictures:
Balme his foule head in warme distilled waters,
And burne ſweet Wood to make the Lodging ſweete:
Procure me Musicke readie when he wakes,
To make a dulcet and a heauenly ſound:
And if he chance to ſpeake, be readie ſtraight
(And with a lowe ſubmiſſiue reuerence)
Say, what is it your Honor wil command:
Let one attend him with a ſiluer Bason
Full of Rose-water, and bestrew’d with Flowers,
Another beare the Ewer: the third a Diaper,
And ſay wilt please your Lordship coole your hands.
Some one be readie with a costly ſuite,
And aske him what apparrel he will weare:
Another tell him of his Hounds and Horse,
And that his Ladie mournes at his disease,
Perswade him that he hath bin Lunaticke,
And when he ſayes he is, ſay that he dreames,
For he is nothing but a mightie Lord:
This do, and do it kindly, gentle ſirs,
It wil be pastime paſſing excellent,
If it be husbanded with modestie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Hunts.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord I warrant you we wil play our part
As he ſhall thinke by our true diligence
He is no leſſe then what we ſay he is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Take him vp gently, and to bed with him,
And each one to his office when he wakes.
Sirrah, go ſee what Trumpet ‘tis that ſounds,
Belike ſome Noble Gentleman that meanes
(Trauelling ſome iourney) to repose him heere.
How now? who is it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: An't please your Honor, Players
That offer ſeruice to your Lordship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Bid them come neere:
Now fellowes, you are welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Players.
SPEECH.LINE: We thanke your Honor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you intend to ſtay with me to night?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Player.
SPEECH.LINE: So please your Lordshippe to accept our dutie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: With all my heart. This fellow I remember,
Since once he plaide a Farmers eldest ſonne,
'Twas where you woo’d the Gentlewoman ſo well:
I haue forgot your name: but ſure that part
Was aptly fitted, and naturally perform’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sincklo.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke 'twas Soto that your honor meanes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis verie true, thou didst it excellent:
Well you are come to me in happie time,
The rather for I haue ſome ſport in hand,
Wherein your cunning can aſſist me much.
There is a Lord will heare you play to night;
But I am doubtfull of your modesties,
Least (ouer-eying of his odde behauiour,
For yet his honor neuer heard a play)
You breake into ſome merrie paſſion,
And ſo offend him: for I tell you ſirs,
If you ſhould ſmile, he growes impatient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Plai.
SPEECH.LINE: Feare not my Lord, we can contain our ſelues,
Were he the veriest anticke in the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Go ſirra, take them to the Butterie,
And giue them friendly welcome euerie one,
Let them want nothing that my house affoords.
Sirra go you to Bartholmew my Page,
And ſee him drest in all ſuites like a Ladie:
That done, conduct him to the drunkards chamber,
And call him Madam, do him obeisance:
Tell him from me (as he will win my loue)
He beare himselfe with honourable action,
Such as he hath obseru’d in noble Ladies
Vnto their Lords, by them accomplished,
Such dutie to the drunkard let him do:
With ſoft lowe tongue, and lowly curtesie,
And ſay: What is't your Honor will command,
Wherein your Ladie, and your humble wife,
May ſhew her dutie, and make knowne her loue.
And then with kinde embracements, tempting kiſſes,
And with declining head into his bosome
Bid him ſhed teares, as being ouer-ioyed
To ſee her noble Lord restor’d to health,
Who for this ſeuen yeares hath esteemed him
No better then a poore and loathsome begger:
And if the boy haue not a womans guift
To raine a ſhower of commanded teares,
An Onion wil do well for ſuch a ſhift,
Which in a Napkin (being close conuei’d)
Shall in despight enforce a waterie eie:
See this dispatch’d with all the hast thou canst,
Anon Ile giue thee more instructions.
I know the boy will wel vsurpe the grace,
Voice, gate, and action of a Gentlewoman:
I long to heare him call the drunkard husband,
And how my men will ſtay themselues from laughter,
When they do homage to this ſimple peasant,
Ile in to counsell them: haply my presence
May well abate the ouer-merrie ſpleene,
Which otherwise would grow into extreames.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter aloft the drunkard with attendants, ſome with apparel, Bason and Ewer, & other appurtenances, & Lord

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: For Gods ſake a pot of ſmall Ale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt please your Lord drink a cup of ſacke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt please your Honor taste of these Con-serues?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: What raiment wil your honor weare to day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: I am Christophero Sly, call not mee Honour nor Lordship: I ne're drank ſacke in my life: and if you giue me any Conserues, giue me conserues of Beefe: nere ask me what raiment Ile weare, for I haue no more doub-lets then backes: no more ſtockings then legges: nor no more ſhoœs then feet, nay ſometime more feete then ſhoœs, or ſuch ſhoœs as my tœs looke through the o-uer-leather. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauen cease this idle humor in your Honor.
Oh that a mightie man of ſuch discent,
Of ſuch poſſeſſions, and ſo high esteeme
Should be infused with ſo foule a ſpirit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: What would you make me mad? Am not I Chri-stopher Slie, old Slies ſonne of Burton-heath, by byrth a Pedler, by education a Cardmaker, by transmutation a Beare-heard, and now by present profeſſion a Tinker. Aske Marrian Hacket the fat Alewife of Wincot, if ſhee know me not: if ſhe ſay I am not xiiii.d. on the ſcore for ſheere Ale, ſcore me vp for the lyingst knaue in Christen dome. What I am not bestraught: here's—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Man.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh this it is that makes your Ladie mourne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Man.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh this is it that makes your ſeruants droop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Hence comes it, that your kindred ſhuns your house
As beaten hence by your ſtrange Lunacie.
Oh Noble Lord, bethinke thee of thy birth,
Call home thy ancient thoughts from banishment,
And banish hence these abiect lowlie dreames:
Looke how thy ſeruants do attend on thee,
Each in his office readie at thy becke.
Wilt thou haue Musicke? Harke Apollo plaies,
And twentie caged Nightingales do ſing.
Or wilt thou ſleepe? Wee'l haue thee to a Couch,
Softer and ſweeter then the lustfull bed
On purpose trim’d vp for Semiramis.
Say thou wilt walke: we wil bestrow the ground.
Or wilt thou ride? Thy horses ſhal be trap’d,
Their harneſſe ſtudded all with Gold and Pearle.
Dost thou loue hawking? Thou hast hawkes will ſoare
Aboue the morning Larke. Or wilt thou hunt,
Thy hounds ſhall make the Welkin anſwer them
And fetch ſhrill ecchœs from the hollow earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Man.
SPEECH.LINE: Say thou wilt course, thy gray-hounds are as ſwift
As breathed Stags: I fleeter then the Rœ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.M.
SPEECH.LINE: Dost thou loue pictures? we wil fetch thee ſtrait
Adonis painted by a running brooke,
And Citherea all in ſedges hid,
Which ſeeme to moue and wanton with her breath,
Euen as the wauing ſedges play with winde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'l ſhew thee Io, as ſhe was a Maid,
And how ſhe was beguiled and ſurpriz’d,
As liuelie painted, as the deede was done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Man.
SPEECH.LINE: Or Daphne roming through a thornie wood,
Scratching her legs, that one ſhal ſweare ſhe bleeds,
And at that ſight ſhal ſad Apollo weepe,
So workmanlie the blood and teares are drawne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art a Lord, and nothing but a Lord:
Thou hast a Ladie farre more Beautifull,
Then any woman in this waining age.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Man.
SPEECH.LINE: And til the teares that ſhe hath ſhed for thee,
Like enuious flouds ore-run her louely face,
She was the fairest creature in the world,
And yet ſhee is inferiour to none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: Am I a Lord, and haue I ſuch a Ladie?
Or do I dreame? Or haue I dream’d till now?
I do not ſleepe: I ſee, I heare, I ſpeake:
I ſmel ſweet ſauours, and I feele ſoft things:
Vpon my life I am a Lord indeede,
And not a Tinker, nor Christopher Slie.
Well, bring our Ladie hither to our ſight,
And once againe a pot o'th ſmallest Ale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Man.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt please your mightineſſe to wash your hands: Oh how we ioy to ſee your wit restor’d, Oh that once more you knew but what you are: These fifteene yeeres you haue bin in a dreame, Or when you wak’d, ſo wak’d as if you ſlept.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: These fifteene yeeres, by my fay, a goodly nap,
But did I neuer ſpeake of all that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Man.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh yes my Lord, but verie idle words,
For though you lay heere in this goodlie chamber,
Yet would you ſay, ye were beaten out of doore,
And raile vpon the Hosteſſe of the house,
And ſay you would present her at the Leete,
Because ſhe brought ſtone-Iugs, and no ſeal’d quarts:
Sometimes you would call out for Cicely Hacket.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: I, the womans maide of the house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Man.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir you know no house, nor no ſuch maid
Nor no ſuch men as you haue reckon’d vp,
As Stephen Slie, and old Iohn Naps of Greece,
And Peter Turph, and Henry Pimpernell,
And twentie more ſuch names and men as these,
Which neuer were, nor no man euer ſaw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Lord be thanked for my good amends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke thee, thou ſhalt not loose by it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lady.
SPEECH.LINE: How fares my noble Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie I fare well, for heere is cheere enough.
Where is my wife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere noble Lord, what is thy will with her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you my wife, and will not cal me husband?
My men ſhould call me Lord, I am your good-man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: My husband and my Lord, my Lord and husband
I am your wife in all obedience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: I know it well, what must I call her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: Alce Madam, or Ione Madam?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, and nothing else, ſo Lords cal Ladies

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: Madame wife, they ſay that I haue dream’d,
And ſlept aboue ſome fifteene yeare or more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lady.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and the time ſeeme's thirty vnto me,
Being all this time abandon’d from your bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis much, ſeruants leaue me and her alone:
Madam vndreſſe you, and come now to bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Thrice noble Lord, let me intreat of you
To pardon me yet for a night or two:
Or if not ſo, vntill the Sun be ſet.
For your Physitians haue expreſſely charg’d,
In perill to incurre your former malady,
That I ſhould yet absent me from your bed:
I hope this reason ſtands for my excuse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: I, it ſtands ſo that I may hardly tarry ſo long: But I would be loth to fall into my dreames againe: I wil therefore tarrie in despight of the flesh & the blood

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Honors Players hearing your amendment,
Are come to play a pleasant Comedie,
For ſo your doctors hold it very meete,
Seeing too much ſadneſſe hath congeal’d your blood,
And melancholly is the Nurse of frenzie,
Therefore they thought it good you heare a play,
And frame your minde to mirth and merriment,
Which barres a thousand harmes, and lengthens life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie I will let them play, it is not a Comon-tie, a Christmas gambold, or a tumbling tricke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lady.
SPEECH.LINE: No my good Lord, it is more pleasing ſtuffe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: What, houshold ſtuffe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lady.
SPEECH.LINE: It is a kinde of history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, we'l ſee't:
Come Madam wife ſit by my ſide,
And let the world ſlip, we ſhall nere be yonger.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Enter Lucentio, and his man Triano.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Tranio, ſince for the great desire I had
To ſee faire Padua, nurserie of Arts,
I am arriu’d for fruitfull Lumbardie,
The pleasant garden of great Italy,
And by my fathers loue and leaue am arm’d
With his good will, and thy good companie.
My trustie ſeruant well approu’d in all,
Heere let vs breath, and haply institute
A course of Learning, and ingenious ſtudies.
Pisa renowned for graue Citizens
Gaue me my being, and my father first
A Merchant of great Trafficke through the world:
Vincentio's come of the Bentiuolij,
Vincentio's ſonne, brought vp in Florence,
It ſhall become to ſerue all hopes conceiu’d
To decke his fortune with his vertuous deedes:
And therefore Tranio, for the time I ſtudie,
Vertue and that part of Philosophie
Will I applie, that treats of happineſſe,
By vertue ſpecially to be atchieu’d.
Tell me thy minde, for I haue Pisa left,
And am to Padua come, as he that leaues
A ſhallow plash, to plunge him in the deepe,
And with ſacietie ſeekes to quench his thirst.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Me Pardonato, gentle master mine:
I am in all affected as your ſelfe,
Glad that you thus continue your resolue,
To ſucke the ſweets of ſweete Philosophie.
Onely (good master) while we do admire
This vertue, and this morall discipline,
Let's be no Stoickes, nor no ſtockes I pray,
Or ſo deuote to Aristotles checkes
As Ouid; be an out-cast quite abiur’d:
Balke Lodgicke with acquaintance that you haue,
And practise Rhetoricke in your common talke,
Musicke and Pœsie vse, to quicken you,
The Mathematickes, and the Metaphysickes
Fall to them as you finde your ſtomacke ſerues you:
No profit growes, where is no pleasure tane:
In briefe ſir, ſtudie what you mo’t affect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Gramercies Tranio, well dost thou aduise,
If Biondello thou wert come ashore,
We could at once put vs in readineſſe,
And take a Lodging fit to entertaine
Such friends (as time) in Padua ſhall beget.
But ſtay a while, what companie is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Master ſome ſhew to welcome vs to Towne.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Baptista with his two daughters, Katerina & Bianca, Gremio a Pantelowne, Hortentio ſister to Bianca. Lucen. Tranio, ſtand by

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentlemen, importune me no farther,
For how I firmly am resolu’d you know:
That is, not to bestow my yongest daughter,
Before I haue a husband for the elder:
If either of you both loue Katherina,
Because I know you well, and loue you well,
Leaue ſhall you haue to court her at your pleasure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: To cart her rather. She's to rough for mee,
There, there Hortensio, will you any Wife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you ſir, is it your will
To make a ſtale of me amongst these mates?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Mates maid, how meane you that?
No mates for you,
Vnleſſe you were of gentler milder mould.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: I'faith ſir, you ſhall neuer neede to feare,
I-wis it is not halfe way to her heart:
But if it were, doubt not, her care ſhould be,
To combe your noddle with a three-legg’d ſtoole,
And paint your face, and vse you like a foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: From all ſuch diuels, good Lord deliuer vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: And me too, good Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Husht master, heres ſome good pastime toward;
That wench is ſtarke mad, or wonderfull froward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lucen.
SPEECH.LINE: But in the others ſilence do I ſee,
Maids milde behauiour and ſobrietie.
Peace Tranio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſaid Mr, mum, and gaze your fill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentlemen, that I may ſoone make good
What I haue ſaid, Bianca get you in,
And let it not displease thee good Bianca,
For I will loue thee nere the leſſe my girle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: A pretty peate, it is best put finger in the eye, and ſhe knew why.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: Sister content you, in my discontent.
Sir, to your pleasure humbly I ſubscribe:
My bookes and instruments ſhall be my companie,
On them to looke, and practise by my ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Harke Tranio, thou maist heare Minerua ſpeak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Signior Baptista, will you be ſo ſtrange,
Sorrie am I that our good will effects
Bianca's greefe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Why will you mew her vp
(Signior Baptista) for this fiend of hell,
And make her beare the pennance of her tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentlemen content ye: I am resolud:
Go in Bianca.
And for I know ſhe taketh mo’t delight
In Musicke, Instruments, and Pœtry,
Schoolemasters will I keepe within my house,
Fit to instruct her youth. If you Hortensio,
Or ſignior Gremio you know any ſuch,
Preferre them hither: for to cunning men,
I will be very kinde and liberall,
To mine owne children, in good bringing vp,
And ſo farewell: Katherina you may ſtay,
For I haue more to commune with Bianca.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, and I trust I may go too, may I not?
What ſhall I be appointed houres, as though
(Belike) I knew not what to take,
And what to leaue? Ha.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: You may go to the diuels dam: your guifts are ſo good heere's none will holde you: Their loue is not ſo great Hortensio, but we may blow our nails together, and fast it fairely out. Our cakes dough on both ſides. Farewell: yet for the loue I beare my ſweet Bianca, if I can by any meanes light on a fit man to teach her that wherein ſhe delights, I will wish him to her father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: So will I ſigniour Gremio: but a word I pray: Though the nature of our quarrell yet neuer brook’d parle, know now vpon aduice, it toucheth vs both: that we may yet againe haue acceſſe to our faire Mistris, and be happie riuals in Bianca's loue, to labour and effect one thing ſpecially.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: What's that I pray?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie ſir to get a husband for her Sister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: A husband: a diuell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay a husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay, a diuell: Think'st thou Hortensio, though her father be verie rich, any man is ſo verie a foole to be married to hell?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Tuſh Gremio: though it paſſe your patience & mine to endure her lowd alarums, why man there bee good fellowes in the world, and a man could light on them, would take her with all faults, and mony enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot tell: but I had as lief take her dowrie with this condition; To be whipt at the hie croſſe euerie morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith (as you ſay) there's ſmall choise in rotten apples: but come, ſince this bar in law makes vs friends, it ſhall be ſo farre forth friendly maintain’d, till by hel-ping Baptistas eldest daughter to a husband, wee ſet his yongest free for a husband, and then haue too't afresh: Sweet Bianca, happy man be his dole: hee that runnes fastest, gets the Ring: How ſay you ſignior Gremio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grem.
SPEECH.LINE: I am agreed, and would I had giuen him the best horse in Padua to begin his woing that would tho-roughly wœ her, wed her, and bed her, and ridde the house of her. Come on.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt ambo. Manet Tranio and Lucentio

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray ſir tel me, is it poſſible
That loue ſhould of a ſodaine take ſuch hold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Tranio, till I found it to be true,
I neuer thought it poſſible or likely.
But ſee, while idely I ſtood looking on,
I found the effect of Loue in idleneſſe,
And now in plainneſſe do confeſſe to thee
That art to me as ſecret and as deere
As Anna to the Queene of Carthage was:
Tranio I burne, I pine, I perish Tranio,
If I atchieue not this yong modest gyrle:
Counsaile me Tranio, for I know thou canst:
Aſſist me Tranio, for I know thou wilt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Master, it is no time to chide you now,
Affection is not rated from the heart:
If loue haue touch’d you, naught remaines but ſo,
Redime te captam quam queas minimo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Gramercies Lad: Go forward, this contents,
The rest wil comfort, for thy counsels ſound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Master, you look’d ſo longly on the maide,
Perhaps you mark’d not what’s the pith of all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh yes, I ſaw ſweet beautie in her face,
Such as the daughter of Agenor had,
That made great Ioue to humble him to her hand,
When with his knees he kist the Cretan ſtrond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Saw you no more? Mark’d you not how hir ſister
Began to ſcold, and raise vp ſuch a ſtorme,
That mortal eares might hardly indure the din.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Tranio, I ſaw her corrall lips to moue,
And with her breath ſhe did perfume the ayre,
Sacred and ſweet was all I ſaw in her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, then ‘tis time to ſtirre him fro[m] his trance:
I pray awake ſir: if you loue the Maide,
Bend thoughts and wits to atcheeue her. Thus it ſtands:
Her elder ſister is ſo curst and ſhrew’d,
That til the Father rid his hands of her,
Master, your Loue must liue a maide at home,
And therefore has he closely meu’d her vp,
Because ſhe will not be annoy’d with ſuters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Ah Tranio, what a cruell Fathers he:
But art thou not aduis’d, he tooke ſome care
To get her cunning Schoolemasters to instruct her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: I marry am I ſir, and now ‘tis plotted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue it Tranio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Master, for my hand,
Both our inuentions meet and iumpe in one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell me thine first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: You will be ſchoole-master,
And vndertake the teaching of the maid:
That's your deuice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: It is: May it be done?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Not poſſible: for who ſhall beare your part,
And be in Padua heere Vincentio's ſonne,
Keepe house, and ply his booke, welcome his friends,
Visit his Countrimen, and banquet them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Basta, content thee: for I haue it full.
We haue not yet bin ſeene in any house,
Nor can we be distinguish’d by our faces,
For man or master: then it followes thus;
Thou ſhalt be master, Tranio in my ſted:
Keepe house, and port, and ſeruants, as I ſhould,
I will ſome other be, ſome Florentine,
Some Neapolitan, or meaner man of Pisa.
‘Tis hatch’d, and ſhall be ſo: Tranio at once
Vncase thee: take my Coulord hat and cloake,
When Biondello comes, he waites on thee,
But I will charme him first to keepe his tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: So had you neede:
In breefe Sir, ſith it your pleasure is,
And I am tyed to be obedient,
For ſo your father charg’d me at our parting:
Be ſeruiceable to my ſonne (quoth he)
Although I thinke 'twas in another ſense,
I am content to bee Lucentio,
Because ſo well I loue Lucentio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Tranio be ſo, because Lucentio loues,
And let me be a ſlaue, t’ atchieue that maide,
Whose ſodaine ſight hath thral’d my wounded eye.
Heere comes the rogue. Sirra, where haue you bin?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: Where haue I beene? Nay how now, where are you? Maister, ha's my fellow Tranio ſtolne your cloathes, or you ſtolne his, or both? Pray what’s the newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirra come hither, ‘tis no time to iest,
And therefore frame your manners to the time
Your fellow Tranio heere to ſaue my life,
Puts my apparrell, and my count'nance on,
And I for my escape haue put on his:
For in a quarrell ſince I came a-shore,
I kil’d a man, and feare I was descried:
Waite you on him, I charge you, as becomes:
While I make way from hence to ſaue my life:
You vnderstand me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir, ne're a whit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: And not a iot of Tranio in your mouth,
Tranio is chang’d into Lucentio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: The better for him, would I were ſo too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: So could I 'faith boy, to haue the next wish af-ter, that Lucentio indeede had Baptistas yongest daugh-ter. But ſirra, not for my ſake, but your masters, I ad-uise you vse your manners discreetly in all kind of com-panies: When I am alone, why then I am Tranio: but in all places else, your master Lucentio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Tranio let's go:
One thing more rests, that thy ſelfe execute,
To make one among these woœrs: if thou ask me why,
Sufficeth my reasons are both good and waighty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Man.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord you nod, you do not minde the play.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes by Saint Anne do I, a good matter ſurely:
Comes there any more of it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lady.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, ‘tis but begun.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beg.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis a verie excellent peece of worke, Madame
Ladie: would 'twere done.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Petruchio, and his man Grumio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Verona, for a while I take my leaue,
To ſee my friends in Padua; but of all
My best beloued and approued friend
Hortensio: & I trow this is his house:
Heere ſirra Grumio, knocke I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Knocke ſir? whom ſhould I knocke? Is there any man ha's rebus’d your worship?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Villaine I ſay, knocke me heere ſoundly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Knocke you heere ſir? Why ſir, what am I ſir, that I ſhould knocke you heere ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Villaine I ſay, knocke me at this gate,
And rap me well, or Ile knocke your knaues pate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: My Mr is growne quarrelsome:
I ſhould knocke you first,
And then I know after who comes by the worst.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Will it not be?
'Faith ſirrah, and you'l not knocke, Ile ring it,
Ile trie how you can Sol, Fa, and ſing it.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: He rings him by the eares

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Helpe mistris helpe, my master is mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Now knocke when I bid you: ſirrah villaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, what’s the matter? My olde friend Grumio, and my good friend Petruchio? How do you all at Verona?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Signior Hortensio, come you to part the fray?
Contutti le core bene trobatto, may I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Alla nostra casa bene venuto multo honorata ſigni-or mio Petruchio. Rise Grumio rise, we will compound this quarrell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay ‘tis no matter ſir, what he leges in Latine. If this be not a lawfull cause for me to leaue his ſeruice, looke you ſir: He bid me knocke him, & rap him ſound-ly ſir. Well, was it fit for a ſeruant to vse his master ſo, being perhaps (for ought I ſee) two and thirty, a peepe out? Whom would to God I had well knockt at first, then had not Grumio come by the worst.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſenceleſſe villaine: good Hortensio,
I bad the rascall knocke vpon your gate,
And could not get him for my heart to do it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Knocke at the gate? O heauens: ſpake you not these words plaine? Sirra, Knocke me heere: rappe me heere: knocke me well, and knocke me ſoundly? And come you now with knocking at the gate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirra be gone, or talke not I aduise you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Petruchio patience, I am Grumio's pledge:
Why this a heauie chance twixt him and you,
Your ancient trustie pleasant ſeruant Grumio:
And tell me now (sweet friend) what happie gale
Blowes you to Padua heere, from old Verona?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Such wind as ſcatters yongmen throgh y world,
To ſeeke their fortunes farther then at home,
Where ſmall experience growes but in a few.
Signior Hortensio, thus it ſtands with me,
Antonio my father is deceast,
And I haue thrust my ſelfe into this maze,
Happily to wiue and thriue, as best I may:
Crownes in my purse I haue, and goods at home,
And ſo am come abroad to ſee the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Petruchio, ſhall I then come roundly to thee,
And wish thee to a ſhrew’d ill-fauour’d wife?
Thou’dst thanke me but a little for my counsell:
And yet Ile promise thee ſhe ſhall be rich,
And verie rich: but th’art too much my friend,
And Ile not wish thee to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Signior Hortensio, 'twixt ſuch friends as wee,
Few words ſuffice: and therefore, if thou know
One rich enough to be Petruchio's wife:
(As wealth is burthen of my woing dance)
Be ſhe as foule as was Florentius Loue,
As old as Sibell, and as curst and ſhrow’d
As Socrates Zentippe, or a worse:
She moues me not, or not remoues at least
Affections edge in me. Were ſhe is as rough
As are the ſwelling Adriaticke ſeas.
I come to wiue it wealthily in Padua:
If wealthily, then happily in Padua.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay looke you ſir, hee tels you flatly what his minde is: why giue him Gold enough, and marrie him to a Puppet or an Aglet babie, or an old trot with ne're a tooth in her head, though ſhe haue as manie diseases as two and fiftie horses. Why nothing comes amiſſe, ſo monie comes withall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Petruchio, ſince we are ſtept thus farre in,
I will continue that I broach’d in iest,
I can Petruchio helpe thee to a wife
With wealth enough, and yong and beautious,
Brought vp as best becomes a Gentlewoman.
Her onely fault, and that is faults enough,
Is, that ſhe is intollerable curst,
And ſhrow’d, and froward, ſo beyond all measure,
That were my ſtate farre worser then it is,
I would not wed her for a mine of Gold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Hortensio peace: thou knowst not golds effect,
Tell me her fathers name, and ‘tis enough:
For I will boord her, though ſhe chide as loud
As thunder, when the clouds in Autumne cracke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Her father is Baptista Minola,
An affable and courteous Gentleman,
Her name is Katherina Minola,
Renown’d in Padua for her ſcolding tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: I know her father, though I know not her,
And he knew my deceased father well:
I wil not ſleepe Hortensio til I ſee her,
And therefore let me be thus bold with you,
To giue you ouer at this first encounter,
Vnleſſe you wil accompanie me thither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru
SPEECH.LINE: . I pray you Sir let him go while the humor lasts. A my word, and ſhe knew him as wel as I do, ſhe would thinke ſcolding would doe little good vpon him. Shee may perhaps call him halfe a ſcore Knaues, or ſo: Why that’s nothing; and he begin once, hee'l raile in his rope trickes. Ile tell you what ſir, and ſhe ſtand him but a li-tle, he wil throw a figure in her face, and ſo disfigure hir with it, that ſhee ſhal haue no more eies to ſee withall then a Cat: you know him not ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Tarrie Petruchio, I must go with thee,
For in Baptistas keepe my treasure is:
He hath the Iewel of my life in hold,
His yongest daughter, beautiful Bianca,
And her with-holds from me. Other more
Suters to her, and riuals in my Loue:
Supposing it a thing impoſſible,
For those defects I haue before rehearst,
That euer Katherina wil be woo’d:
Therefore this order hath Baptista tane,
That none ſhal haue acceſſe vnto Bianca,
Til Katherine the Curst, haue got a husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Katherine the curst,
A title for a maide, of all titles the worst.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Now ſhal my friend Petruchio do me grace,
And offer me disguis’d in ſober robes,
To old Baptista as a ſchoole-master
Well ſeene in Musicke, to instruct Bianca,
That ſo I may by this deuice at least
Haue leaue and leisure to make loue to her,
And vnsuspected court her by her ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere's no knauerie. See, to beguile the olde-folkes, how the young folkes lay their heads together. Master, master, looke about you: Who goes there? ha.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace Grumio, it is the riuall of my Loue.
Petruchio ſtand by a while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grumio.
SPEECH.LINE: A proper ſtripling, and an amorous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gremio.
SPEECH.LINE: O very well, I haue perus’d the note:
Hearke you ſir, Ile haue them verie fairely bound,
All bookes of Loue, ſee that at any hand,
And ſee you reade no other Lectures to her:
You vnderstand me. Ouer and beside
Signior Baptistas liberalitie,
Ile mend it with a Largeſſe. Take your paper too,
And let me haue them verie wel perfum’d;
For ſhe is ſweeter then perfume it ſelfe
To whom they go to: what wil you reade to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: What ere I reade to her, Ile pleade for you,
As for my patron, ſtand you ſo aſſur’d,
As firmely as your ſelfe were ſtill in place,
Yea and perhaps with more ſucceſſefull words
Then you; vnleſſe you were a ſcholler ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh this learning, what a thing it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh this Woodcocke, what an Aſſe it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petru.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace ſirra.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Grumio mum: God ſaue you ſignior Gremio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: And you are wel met, Signior Hortensio.
Trow you whither I am going? To Baptista Minola,
I promist to enquire carefully
About a ſchoolemaster for the faire Bianca,
And by good fortune I haue lighted well
On this yong man: For learning and behauiour
Fit for her turne, well read in Pœtrie
And other bookes, good ones, I warrant ye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis well: and I haue met a Gentleman
Hath promist me to helpe one to another,
A fine Musitian to instruct our Mistris,
So ſhal I no whit be behinde in dutie
To faire Bianca, ſo beloued of me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Beloued of me, and that my deeds ſhal proue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: And that his bags ſhal proue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Gremio, ‘tis now no time to vent our loue,
Listen to me, and if you ſpeake me faire,
Ile tel you newes indifferent good for either.
Heere is a Gentleman whom by chance I met
Vpon agreement from vs to his liking,
Will vndertake to woo curst Katherine,
Yea, and to marrie her, if her dowrie please.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: So ſaid, ſo done, is well:
Hortensio, haue you told him all her faults?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: I know ſhe is an irkesome brawling ſcold:
If that be all Masters, I heare no harme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: No, ſayst me ſo, friend? What Countreyman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Borne in Verona, old Butonios ſonne:
My father dead, my fortune liues for me,
And I do hope, good dayes and long, to ſee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ſir, ſuch a life with ſuch a wife, were ſtrange:
But if you haue a ſtomacke, too't a Gods name,
You ſhal haue me aſſisting you in all.
But will you woo this Wilde-cat?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Will I liue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Wil he woo her? I: or Ile hang her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Why came I hither, but to that intent?
Thinke you, a little dinne can daunt mine eares?
Haue I not in my time heard Lions rore?
Haue I not heard the ſea, puft vp with windes,
Rage like an angry Boare, chafed with ſweat?
Haue I not heard great Ordnance in the field?
And heauens Artillerie thunder in the ſkies?
Haue I not in a pitched battell heard
Loud larums, neighing ſteeds, & trumpets clangue?
And do you tell me of a womans tongue?
That giues not halfe ſo great a blow to heare,
As wil a Cheſſe-nut in a Farmers fire.
Tuſh, tuſh, feare boyes with bugs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: For he feares none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grem.
SPEECH.LINE: Hortensio hearke:
This Gentleman is happily arriu’d,
My minde presumes for his owne good, and yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: I promist we would be Contributors,
And beare his charge of wooing whatsœre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gremio.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo we wil, prouided that he win her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: I would I were as ſure of a good dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentlemen God ſaue you. If I may be bold
Tell me I beseech you, which is the readiest way
To the house of Signior Baptista Minola?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: He that ha's the two faire daughters: ist he you meane?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen he Biondello.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Hearke you ſir, you meane not her to—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Perhaps him and her ſir, what haue you to do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Not her that chides ſir, at any hand I pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tranio.
SPEECH.LINE: I loue no chiders ſir: Biondello, let's away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Well begun Tranio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, a word ere you go:
Are you a ſutor to the Maid you talke of, yea or no?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: And if I be ſir, is it any offence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gremio.
SPEECH.LINE: No: if without more words you will get you hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, I pray are not the ſtreets as free
For me, as for you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſo is not ſhe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: For what reason I beseech you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: For this reason if you'l kno,
That ſhe's the choise loue of Signior Gremio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſhe's the chosen of ſignior Hortensio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Softly my Masters: If you be Gentlemen
Do me this right: heare me with patience.
Baptista is a noble Gentleman,
To whom my Father is not all vnknowne,
And were his daughter fairer then ſhe is,
She may more ſutors haue, and me for one.
Faire Laedaes daughter had a thousand woœrs,
Then well one more may faire Bianca haue;
And ſo ſhe ſhall: Lucentio ſhal make one,
Though Paris came, in hope to ſpeed alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: What, this Gentleman will out-talke vs all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir giue him head, I know hee'l proue a Iade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Hortensio, to what end are all these words?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, let me be ſo bold as aske you,
Did you yet euer ſee Baptistas daughter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſir, but heare I do that he hath two:
The one, as famous for a ſcolding tongue,
As is the other, for beauteous modestie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, ſir, the first's for me, let her go by.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, leaue that labour to great Hercules,
And let it be more then Alcides twelue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir vnderstand you this of me (insooth)
The yongest daughter whom you hearken for,
Her father keepes from all acceſſe of ſutors,
And will not promise her to any man,
Vntill the elder ſister first be wed.
The yonger then is free, and not before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tranio.
SPEECH.LINE: If it be ſo ſir, that you are the man
Must ſteed vs all, and me amongst the rest:
And if you breake the ice, and do this ſeeke,
Atchieue the elder: ſet the yonger free,
For our acceſſe, whose hap ſhall be to haue her,
Wil not ſo graceleſſe be, to be ingrate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir you ſay wel, and wel you do conceiue,
And ſince you do profeſſe to be a ſutor,
You must as we do, gratifie this Gentleman,
To whom we all rest generally beholding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tranio.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I ſhal not be ſlacke, in ſigne whereof,
Please ye we may contriue this afternoone,
And quaffe carowses to our Mistreſſe health,
And do as aduersaries do in law,
Striue mightily, but eate and drinke as friends.
Gru. Bion.
Oh excellent motion: fellowes let's be gon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: The motions good indeed, and be it ſo,
Petruchio, I ſhal be your Been venuto.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: Good ſister wrong me not, nor wrong your ſelf,
To make a bondmaide and a ſlaue of mee,
That I disdaine: but for these other goods,
Vnbinde my hands, Ile pull them off my ſelfe,
Yea all my raiment, to my petticoate,
Or what you will command me, wil I do,
So well I know my dutie to my elders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Of all thy ſutors heere I charge tel
Whom thou lou'st best: ſee thou diſſemble not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bianca.
SPEECH.LINE: Beleeue me ſister, of all the men aliue,
I neuer yet beheld that ſpeciall face,
Which I could fancie, more then any other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Minion thou lyest: Is't not Hortensio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: If you affect him ſister, heere I ſweare
Ile pleade for you my ſelfe, but you ſhal haue him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh then belike you fancie riches more,
You wil haue Gremio to keepe you faire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it for him you do enuie me ſo?
Nay then you iest, and now I wel perceiue
You haue but iested with me all this while:
I prethee ſister Kate, vntie my hands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ka
SPEECH.LINE: If that be iest, then all the rest was ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Why how now Dame, whence growes this in-solence?
Bianca ſtand aside, poore gyrle ſhe weepes:
Go ply thy Needle, meddle not with her.
For ſhame thou Hilding of a diuellish ſpirit,
Why dost thou wrong her, that did nere wrong thee?
When did ſhe croſſe thee with a bitter word?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Her ſilence flouts me, and Ile be reueng’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap
SPEECH.LINE: What in my ſight? Bianca get thee in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: What will you not ſuffer me: Nay now I ſee
She is your treasure, ſhe must haue a husband,
I must dance bare-foot on her wedding day,
And for your loue to her, leade Apes in hell.
Talke not to me, I will go ſit and weepe,
Till I can finde occasion of reuenge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Was euer Gentleman thus greeu’d as I? But who comes heere.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Gremio, Lucentio, in the habit of a meane man, Petruchio with Tranio, with his boy bearing a Lute and Bookes

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow neighbour Baptista.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow neighbour Gremio: God ſaue you Gentlemen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: And you good ſir: pray haue you not a daugh-ter, cal’d Katerina, faire and vertuous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue a daughter ſir, cal’d Katerina.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: You are too blunt, go to it orderly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: You wrong me ſignior Gremio, giue me leaue.
I am a Gentleman of Verona ſir,
That hearing of her beautie, and her wit,
Her affability and bashfull modestie:
Her wondrous qualities, and milde behauiour,
Am bold to ſhew my ſelfe a forward guest
Within your house, to make mine eye the witneſſe
Of that report, which I ſo oft haue heard,
And for an entrance to my entertainment,
I do present you with a man of mine
Cunning in Musicke, and the Mathematickes,
To instruct her fully in those ſciences,
Whereof I know ſhe is not ignorant,
Accept of him, or else you do me wrong.
His name is Litio, borne in Mantua.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Y'are welcome ſir, and he for your good ſake.
But for my daughter Katerine, this I know,
She is not for your turne, the more my greefe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſee you do not meane to part with her,
Or else you like not of my companie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistake me not, I ſpeake but as I finde,
Whence are you ſir? What may I call your name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Petruchio is my name, Antonio's ſonne,
A man well knowne throughout all Italy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: I know him well: you are welcome for his ſake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Sauing your tale Petruchio, I pray let vs that are poore petitioners ſpeake too? Bacare, you are meruay-lous forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, Pardon me ſignior Gremio, I would faine be doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: I doubt it not ſir. But you will curse
Your wooing neighbors: this is a guift
Very gratefull, I am ſure of it, to expreſſe
The like kindneſſe my ſelfe, that haue beene
More kindely beholding to you then any:
Freely giue vnto this yong Scholler, that hath
Beene long ſtudying at Rhemes, as cunning
In Greeke, Latine, and other Languages,
As the other in Musicke and Mathematickes:
His name is Cambio: pray accept his ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: A thousand thankes ſignior Gremio:
Welcome good Cambio. But gentle ſir,
Me thinkes you walke like a ſtranger,
May I be ſo bold, to know the cause of your comming?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon me ſir, the boldneſſe is mine owne,
That being a ſtranger in this Cittie heere,
Do make my ſelfe a ſutor to your daughter,
Vnto Bianca, faire and vertuous:
Nor is your firme resolue vnknowne to me,
In the preferment of the eldest ſister.
This liberty is all that I request,
That vpon knowledge of my Parentage,
I may haue welcome 'mongst the rest that woo,
And free acceſſe and fauour as the rest.
And toward the education of your daughters:
I heere bestow a ſimple instrument,
And this ſmall packet of Greeke and Latine bookes:
If you accept them, then their worth is great:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Lucentio is your name, of whence I pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Of Pisa ſir, ſonne to Vincentio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: A mightie man of Pisa by report,
I know him well: you are verie welcome ſir:
Take you the Lute, and you the ſet of bookes,
You ſhall go ſee your Pupils presently.
Holla, within.
Sirrah, leade these Gentlemen
To my daughters, and tell them both
These are their Tutors, bid them vse them well,
We will go walke a little in the Orchard,
And then to dinner: you are paſſing welcome,
And ſo I pray you all to thinke your ſelues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Signior Baptista, my busineſſe asketh haste,
And euerie day I cannot come to woo,
You knew my father well, and in him me,
Left ſolie heire to all his Lands and goods,
Which I haue bettered rather then decreast,
Then tell me, if I get your daughters loue,
What dowrie ſhall I haue with her to wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: After my death, the one halfe of my Lands,
And in poſſeſſion twentie thousand Crownes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: And for that dowrie, Ile aſſure her of
Her widdow-hood, be it that ſhe ſuruiue me
In all my Lands and Leases whatsœuer,
Let ſpecialties be therefore drawne betweene vs,
That couenants may be kept on either hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: I, when the ſpeciall thing is well obtain’d,
That is her loue: for that is all in all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Why that is nothing: for I tell you father,
I am as peremptorie as ſhe proud minded:
And where two raging fires meete together,
They do consume the thing that feedes their furie.
Though little fire growes great with little winde,
Yet extreme gusts will blow out fire and all:
So I to her, and ſo ſhe yeelds to me,
For I am rough, and woo not like a babe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Well maist thou woo, and happy be thy ſpeed:
But be thou arm’d for ſome vnhappie words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: I to the proofe, as Mountaines are for windes,
That ſhakes not, though they blow perpetually.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Hortensio with his head broke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: How now my friend, why dost thou looke ſo pale?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: For feare I promise you, if I looke pale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: What, will my daughter proue a good Musiti-an?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke ſhe'l ſooner proue a ſouldier,
Iron may hold with her, but neuer Lutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then thou canst not break her to the Lute?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Why no, for ſhe hath broke the Lute to me:
I did but tell her ſhe mistooke her frets,
And bow’d her hand to teach her fingering,
When (with a mo’t impatient diuellish ſpirit)
Frets call you these? (quoth ſhe) Ile fume with them:
And with that word ſhe ſtroke me on the head,
And through the instrument my pate made way,
And there I ſtood amazed for a while,
As on a Pillorie, looking through the Lute,
While ſhe did call me Rascall, Fidler,
And twangling Iacke, with twentie ſuch vilde tearmes,
As had ſhe ſtudied to misvse me ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Now by the world, it is a lustie Wench,
I loue her ten times more then ere I did,
Oh how I long to haue ſome chat with her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Wel go with me, and be not ſo discomfited.
Proceed in practise with my yonger daughter,
She's apt to learne, and thankefull for good turnes:
Signior Petruchio, will you go with vs,
Or ſhall I ſend my daughter Kate to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you do. Ile attend her heere,
And woo her with ſome ſpirit when ſhe comes,
Say that ſhe raile, why then Ile tell her plaine,
She ſings as ſweetly as a Nightinghale:
Say that ſhe frowne, Ile ſay ſhe lookes as cleere
As morning Roses newly washt with dew:
Say ſhe be mute, and will not ſpeake a word,
Then Ile commend her volubility,
And ſay ſhe vttereth piercing eloquence:
If ſhe do bid me packe, Ile giue her thankes,
As though ſhe bid me ſtay by her a weeke:
If ſhe denie to wed, Ile craue the day
When I ſhall aske the banes, and when be married.
But heere ſhe comes, and now Petruchio ſpeake.
Good morrow Kate, for thats your name I heare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Well haue you heard, but ſomething hard of hearing: They call me Katerine, that do talke of me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: You lye infaith, for you are call’d plaine Kate,
And bony Kate, and ſometimes Kate the curst:
But Kate, the prettiest Kate in Christendome,
Kate of Kate-hall, my ſuper-daintie Kate,
For dainties are all Kates, and therefore Kate
Take this of me, Kate of my consolation,
Hearing thy mildneſſe prais’d in euery Towne,
Thy vertues ſpoke of, and thy beautie ſounded,
Yet not ſo deepely as to thee belongs,
My ſelfe am moou’d to woo thee for my wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Mou’d, in good time, let him that mou’d you hether Remoue you hence: I knew you at the first You were a mouable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, what’s a mouable?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: A ioyn’d ſtoole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast hit it: come ſit on me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Aſſes are made to beare, and ſo are you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Women are made to beare, and ſo are you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſuch Iade as you, if me you meane.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas good Kate, I will not burthen thee,
For knowing thee to be but yong and light.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Too light for ſuch a ſwaine as you to catch,
And yet as heauie as my waight ſhould be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Shold be, ſhould: buzze.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Well tane, and like a buzzard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ſlow-wing’d Turtle, ſhal a buzard take thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: I for a Turtle, as he takes a buzard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come you Waspe, y'faith you are too angrie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: If I be waspish, best beware my ſting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: My remedy is then to plucke it out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: I, if the foole could finde it where it lies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Who knowes not where a Waspe does weare his ſting? In his taile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: In his tongue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Whose tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Yours if you talke of tales, and ſo farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: What with my tongue in your taile.
Nay, come againe, good Kate, I am a Gentleman,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate
SPEECH.LINE: That Ile trie. she ſtrikes him

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſweare Ile cuffe you, if you ſtrike againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: So may you loose your armes,
If you ſtrike me, you are no Gentleman,
And if no Gentleman, why then no armes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: A Herald Kate? Oh put me in thy bookes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: What is your Crest, a Coxcombe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: A combleſſe Cocke, ſo Kate will be my Hen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: No Cocke of mine, you crow too like a crauen

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay come Kate, come: you must not looke ſo ſowre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: It is my fashion when I ſee a Crab.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Why heere's no crab, and therefore looke not ſowre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: There is, there is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ſhew it me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Had I a glaſſe, I would.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: What, you meane my face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Well aym’d of ſuch a yong one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Now by S[aint]. George I am too yong for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet you are wither’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis with cares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: I care not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay heare you Kate. Insooth you ſcape not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: I chafe you if I tarrie. Let me go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: No, not a whit, I finde you paſſing gentle:
'Twas told me you were rough, and coy, and ſullen,
And now I finde report a very liar:
For thou art pleasant, gamesome, paſſing courteous,
But ſlow in ſpeech: yet ſweet as ſpring-time flowers.
Thou canst not frowne, thou canst not looke a ſconce,
Nor bite the lip, as angry wenches will,
Nor hast thou pleasure to be croſſe in talke:
But thou with mildneſſe entertain'st thy woœrs,
With gentle conference, ſoft, and affable.
Why does the world report that Kate doth limpe?
Oh ſland'rous world: Kate like the hazle twig
Is ſtraight, and ſlender, and as browne in hue
As hazle nuts, and ſweeter then the kernels:
Oh let me ſee thee walke: thou dost not halt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Go foole, and whom thou keep'st command.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Did euer Dian ſo become a Groue
As Kate this chamber with her princely gate:
O be thou Dian, and let her be Kate,
And then let Kate be chaste, and Dian ſportfull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Where did you ſtudy all this goodly ſpeech?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: It is extempore, from my mother wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: A witty mother, witleſſe else her ſonne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Am I not wise?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, keepe you warme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry ſo I meane ſweet Katherine in thy bed:
And therefore ſetting all this chat aside,
Thus in plaine termes: your father hath consented
That you ſhall be my wife; your dowry greed on,
And will you, nill you, I will marry you.
Now Kate, I am a husband for your turne,
For by this light, whereby I ſee thy beauty,
Thy beauty that doth make me like thee well,
Thou must be married to no man but me,
For I am he am borne to tame you Kate,
And bring you from a wilde Kate to a Kate
Conformable as other houshold Kates:
Heere comes your father, neuer make deniall,
I must, and will haue Katherine to my wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Signior Petruchio, how ſpeed you with my daughter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: How but well ſir? how but well?
It were impoſſible I ſhould ſpeed amiſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Why how now daughter Katherine, in your dumps?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: Call you me daughter? now I promise you
You haue ſhewd a tender fatherly regard,
To wish me wed to one halfe Lunaticke,
A mad-cap ruffian, and a ſwearing Iacke,
That thinkes with oathes to face the matter out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Father, ‘tis thus, your ſelfe and all the world
That talk’d of her, haue talk’d amiſſe of her:
If ſhe be curst, it is for pollicie,
For ſhee's not froward, but modest as the Doue,
Shee is not hot, but temperate as the morne,
For patience ſhee will proue a ſecond Griſſell,
And Romane Lucrece for her chastitie:
And to conclude, we haue greed ſo well together,
That vpon ſonday is the wedding day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile ſee thee hang’d on ſonday first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Hark Petruchio, ſhe ſaies ſhee'll ſee thee hang’d first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this your ſpeeding? nay the[n] godnight our part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Be patient gentlemen, I choose her for my ſelfe,
If ſhe and I be pleas’d, what’s that to you?
‘Tis bargain’d twixt vs twaine being alone,
That ſhe ſhall ſtill be curst in company.
I tell you ‘tis incredible to beleeue
How much ſhe loues me: oh the kindest Kate,
Shee hung about my necke, and kiſſe on kiſſe
Shee vi’d ſo fast, protesting oath on oath,
That in a twinke ſhe won me to her loue.
Oh you are nouices, ‘tis a world to ſee
How tame when men and women are alone,
A meacocke wretch can make the curstest ſhrew:
Giue me thy hand Kate, I will vnto Venice
To buy apparell 'gainst the wedding day;
Prouide the feast father, and bid the guests,
I will be ſure my Katherine ſhall be fine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not what to ſay, but giue me your ha[n]ds,
God ſend you ioy, Petruchio, ‘tis a match.
Gre. Tra.
Amen ſay we, we will be witneſſes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Father, and wife, and gentlemen adieu,
I will to Venice, ſonday comes apace,
We will haue rings, and things, and fine array,
And kiſſe me Kate, we will be married a ſonday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Was euer match clapt vp ſo ſodainly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith Gentlemen now I play a marchants part,
And venture madly on a desperate Mart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Twas a commodity lay fretting by you,
'Twill bring you gaine, or perish on the ſeas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: The gaine I ſeeke, is quiet me the match.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch:
But now Baptista, to your yonger daughter,
Now is the day we long haue looked for,
I am your neighbour, and was ſuter first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: And I am one that loue Bianca more
Then words can witneſſe, or your thoughts can gueſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Yongling thou canst not loue ſo deare as I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Gray-beard thy loue doth freeze.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: But thine doth frie,
Skipper ſtand backe, ‘tis age that nourisheth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: But youth in Ladies eyes that florisheth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Content you gentlemen, I wil co[m]pound this ſtrife
‘Tis deeds must win the prize, and he of both
That can aſſure my daughter greatest dower,
Shall haue my Biancas loue.
Say ſignior Gremio, what can you aſſure her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: First, as you know, my house within the City
Is richly furnished with plate and gold,
Basons and ewers to laue her dainty hands:
My hangings all of tirian tapestry:
In Iuory cofers I haue ſtuft my crownes:
In Cypres chests my arras counterpoints,
Costly apparell, tents, and Canopies,
Fine Linnen, Turky cushions bost with pearle,
Vallens of Venice gold, in needle worke:
Pewter and braſſe, and all things that belongs
To house or house-keeping: then at my farme
I haue a hundred milch-kine to the pale,
Sixe-score fat Oxen ſtanding in my ſtalls,
And all things answerable to this portion.
My ſelfe am ſtrooke in yeeres I must confeſſe,
And if I die to morrow this is hers,
If whil'st I liue ſhe will be onely mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: That only came well in: ſir, list to me,
I am my fathers heyre and onely ſonne,
If I may haue your daughter to my wife,
Ile leaue her houses three or foure as good
Within rich Pisa walls, as any one
Old Signior Gremio has in Padua,
Besides, two thousand Duckets by the yeere
Of fruitfull land, all which ſhall be her ioynter.
What, haue I pincht you Signior Gremio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Two thousand Duckets by the yeere of land,
My Land amounts not to ſo much in all:
That ſhe ſhall haue, besides an Argosie
That now is lying in Marcellus roade:
What, haue I choakt you with an Argosie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Gremio, ‘tis knowne my father hath no leſſe
Then three great Argosies, besides two Galliaſſes
And twelue tite Gallies, these I will aſſure her,
And twice as much what ere thou offrest next.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I haue offred all, I haue no more,
And ſhe can haue no more then all I haue,
If you like me, ſhe ſhall haue me and mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then the maid is mine from all the world
By your firme promise, Gremio is out-vied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: I must confeſſe your offer is the best,
And let your father make her the aſſurance,
Shee is your owne, else you must pardon me:
If you ſhould die before him, where's her dower?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: That's but a cauill: he is olde, I young.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: And may not yong men die as well as old?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Well gentlemen, I am thus resolu’d,
On ſonday next, you know
My daughter Katherine is to be married:
Now on the ſonday following, ſhall Bianca
Be Bride to you, if you make this aſſurance:
If not, to Signior Gremio:
And ſo I take my leaue, and thanke you both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Adieu good neighbour: now I feare thee not:
Sirra, yong gamester, your father were a foole
To giue thee all, and in his wayning age
Set foot vnder thy table: tut, a toy,
An olde Italian foxe is not ſo kinde my boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: A vengeance on your crafty withered hide,
Yet I haue fac’d it with a card of ten:
‘Tis in my head to doe my master good:
I ſee no reason but ſuppos’d Lucentio
Must get a father, call’d ſuppos’d Vincentio,
And that’s a wonder: fathers commonly
Doe get their children: but in this case of woing,
A childe ſhall get a ſire, if I faile not of my cunning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Fidler forbeare, you grow too forward Sir,
Haue you ſo ſoone forgot the entertainment
Her ſister Katherine welcom’d you withall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: But wrangling pedant, this is
The patroneſſe of heauenly harmony:
Then giue me leaue to haue prerogatiue,
And when in Musicke we haue ſpent an houre,
Your Lecture ſhall haue leisure for as much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Preposterous Aſſe that neuer read ſo farre,
To know the cause why musicke was ordain’d:
Was it not to refresh the minde of man
After his ſtudies, or his vsuall paine?
Then giue me leaue to read Philosophy,
And while I pause, ſerue in your harmony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirra, I will not beare these braues of thine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bianc.
SPEECH.LINE: Why gentlemen, you doe me double wrong,
To ſtriue for that which resteth in my choice:
I am no breeching ſcholler in the ſchooles,
Ile not be tied to howres, nor pointed times,
But learne my Leſſons as I please my ſelfe,
And to cut off all ſtrife: heere ſit we downe,
Take you your instrument, play you the whiles,
His Lecture will be done ere you haue tun’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: You'll leaue his Lecture when I am in tune?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: That will be neuer, tune your instrument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: Where left we last?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere Madam: Hic Ibat Simois, hic est ſigeria tellus, hic ſteterat Priami regia Celsa ſenis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: Conster them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Hic Ibat, as I told you before, Simois, I am Lu-centio, hic est, ſonne vnto Vincentio of Pisa, Sigeria tel-lus, disguised thus to get your loue, hic ſteterat, and that Lucentio that comes a wooing, priami, is my man Tra-nio, regia, bearing my port, celsa ſenis that we might be-guile the old Pantalowne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, my Instrument's in tune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's heare, oh fie, the treble iarres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Spit in the hole man, and tune againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: Now let mee ſee if I can conster it. Hic ibat ſi-mois, I know you not, hic est ſigeria tellus, I trust you not, hic ſtaterat priami, take heede he heare vs not, regia pre-sume not, Celsa ſenis, despaire not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, tis now in tune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: All but the base.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: The base is right, ‘tis the base knaue that iars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: How fiery and forward our Pedant is,
Now for my life the knaue doth court my loue,
Pedascule, Ile watch you better yet:
In time I may beleeue, yet I mistrust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistrust it not, for ſure Aeacides
Was Aiax cald ſo from his grandfather.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: I must beleeue my master, else I promise you,
I ſhould be arguing ſtill vpon that doubt,
But let it rest, now Litio to you:
Good master take it not vnkindly pray
That I haue beene thus pleasant with you both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: You may go walk, and giue me leaue a while,
My Leſſons make no musicke in three parts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you ſo formall ſir, well I must waite
And watch withall, for but I be deceiu’d,
Our fine Musitian groweth amorous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, before you touch the instrument,
To learne the order of my fingering,
I must begin with rudiments of Art,
To teach you gamoth in a briefer ſort,
More pleasant, pithy, and effectuall,
Then hath beene taught by any of my trade,
And there it is in writing fairely drawne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, I am past my gamouth long agœ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet read the gamouth of Hortentio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: Gamouth I am, the ground of all accord:
Are, to plead Hortensio's paſſion:
Beeme, Bianca take him for thy Lord
Cfavt, that loues with all affection:
D ſol re, one Cliffe, two notes haue I,
Ela mi, ſhow pitty or I die,
Call you this gamouth? tut I like it not,
Old fashions please me best, I am not ſo nice
To charge true rules for old inuentions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nicke.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistreſſe, your father prayes you leaue your books,
And helpe to dreſſe your ſisters chamber vp,
You know to morrow is the wedding day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell ſweet masters both, I must be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith Mistreſſe then I haue no cause to ſtay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: But I haue cause to pry into this pedant, Methinkes he lookes as though he were in loue: Yet if thy thoughts Bianca be ſo humble To cast thy wandring eyes on euery ſtale: Seize thee that List, if once I finde thee ranging, Hortensio will be quit with thee by changing. Exit.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Baptista, Gremio, Tranio, Katherine, Bianca, and o-thers, attendants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Signior Lucentio, this is the pointed day
That Katherine and Petruchio ſhould be married,
And yet we heare not of our ſonne in Law:
What will be ſaid, what mockery will it be?
To want the Bride-groome when the Priest attends
To ſpeake the ceremoniall rites of marriage?
What ſaies Lucentio to this ſhame of ours?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſhame but mine, I must forsooth be forst
To giue my hand oppos’d against my heart
Vnto a mad-braine rudesby, full of ſpleene,
Who woo’d in haste, and meanes to wed at leysure:
I told you I, he was a franticke foole,
Hiding his bitter iests in blunt behauiour,
And to be noted for a merry man;
Hee'll woœ a thousand, point the day of marriage,
Make friends, inuite, and proclaime the banes,
Yet neuer meanes to wed where he hath woo’d:
Now must the world point at poore Katherine,
And ſay, lœ, there is mad Petruchio's wife
If it would please him come and marry her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Patience good Katherine and Baptista too,
Vpon my life Petruchio meanes but well,
What euer fortune ſtayes him from his word,
Though he be blunt, I know him paſſing wise,
Though he be merry, yet withall he's honeſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Would Katherine had neuer ſeen him though.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe girle, I cannot blame thee now to weepe,
For ſuch an iniurie would vexe a very ſaint,
Much more a ſhrew of impatient humour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: Master, master, newes, and ſuch newes as you neuer heard of,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it new and olde too? how may that be?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, is it not newes to heard of Petruchio's comming?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Is he come?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: Why no ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: What then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: He is comming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: When will he be heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: When he ſtands where I am, and ſees you there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſay, what to thine olde newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Petruchio is comming, in a new hat and an old ierkin, a paire of old breeches thrice turn’d; a paire of bootes that haue beene candle-cases, one buck-led, another lac’d: an olde rusty ſword tane out of the Towne Armory, with a broken hilt, and chapeleſſe: with two broken points: his horse hip’d with an olde mo-thy ſaddle, and ſtirrops of no kindred: besides poſſest with the glanders, and like to mose in the chine, trou-bled with the Lampaſſe, infected with the fashions, full of Windegalls, ſped with Spauins, raied with the Yel-lowes, past cure of the Fiues, ſtarke ſpoyl’d with the Staggers, begnawne with the Bots, Waid in the backe, and ſhoulder-shotten, neere leg’d before, and with a halfe-chekt Bitte, & a headstall of ſheepes leather, which being restrain’d to keepe him from ſtumbling, hath been often burst, and now repaired with knots: one girth ſixe times peec’d, and a womans Crupper of velure, which hath two letters for her name, fairely ſet down in ſtuds, and heere and there peec’d with packthred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Who comes with him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ſir, his Lackey, for all the world Capari-son’d like the horse: with a linnen ſtock on one leg, and a kersey boot-hose on the other, gartred with a red and blew list; an old hat, & the humor of forty fancies prickt in't for a feather: a monster, a very monster in apparell, & not like a Christian foot-boy, or a gentlemans Lacky.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis ſome od humor pricks him to this fashion,
Yet oftentimes he goes but meane apparel’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad he's come, howsœre he comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, he comes not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Didst thou not ſay hee comes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: Who, that Petruchio came?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: I, that Petruchio came.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſir, I ſay his horse comes with him on his backe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Why that’s all one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay by S[aint]. Iamy, I hold you a penny, a horse and a man is more then one, and yet not many.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, where be these gallants? who's at home?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: You are welcome ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: And yet I come not well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: And yet you halt not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo well apparell’d as I wish you were.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Were it better I ſhould rush in thus:
But where is Kate? where is my louely Bride?
How does my father? gentles methinkes you frowne,
And wherefore gaze this goodly company,
As if they ſaw ſome wondrous monument,
Some Commet, or vnusuall prodigie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, you know this is your wedding day:
First were we ſad, fearing you would not come,
Now ſadder that you come ſo vnprouided:
Fie, doff this habit, ſhame to your estate,
An eye-sore to our ſolemne festiuall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: And tell vs what occasion of import
Hath all ſo long detain’d you from your wife,
And ſent you hither ſo vnlike your ſelfe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Tedious it were to tell, and harsh to heare,
Sufficeth I am come to keepe my word,
Though in ſome part inforced to digreſſe,
Which at more leysure I will ſo excuse,
As you ſhall well be ſatisfied with all.
But where is Kate? I ſtay too long from her,
The morning weares, ‘tis time we were at Church.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: See not your Bride in these vnreuerent robes,
Goe to my chamber, put on clothes of mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Not I, beleeue me, thus Ile visit her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: But thus I trust you will not marry her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Good ſooth euen thus: therefore ha done with words,
To me ſhe's married, not vnto my cloathes:
Could I repaire what ſhe will weare in me,
As I can change these poore accoutrements,
'Twere well for Kate, and better for my ſelfe.
But what a foole am I to chat with you,
When I ſhould bid good morrow to my Bride?
And ſeale the title with a louely kiſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath ſome meaning in his mad attire,
We will perswade him be it poſſible,
To put on better ere he goe to Church.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap
SPEECH.LINE: Ile after him, and ſee the euent of this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſir, Loue concerneth vs to adde
Her fathers liking, which to bring to paſſe
As before imparted to your worship,
I am to get a man what ere he be,
It ſkills not much, weele fit him to our turne,
And he ſhall be Vincentio of Pisa,
And make aſſurance heere in Padua
Of greater ſummes then I haue promised,
So ſhall you quietly enioy your hope,
And marry ſweet Bianca with consent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Were it not that my fellow ſchoolemaster
Doth watch Bianca's ſteps ſo narrowly:
'Twere good me-thinkes to ſteale our marriage,
Which once perform’d, let all the world ſay no,
Ile keepe mine owne despite of all the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: That by degrees we meane to looke into,
And watch our vantage in this busineſſe,
Wee'll ouer-reach the grey-beard Gremio,
The narrow prying father Minola,
The quaint Musician, amorous Litio,
All for my Masters ſake Lucentio.
Signior Gremio, came you from the Church?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: As willingly as ere I came from ſchoole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: And is the Bride & Bridegroom coming home?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: A bridegroome ſay you? ‘tis a groome indeed,
A grumlling groome, and that the girle ſhall finde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Curster then ſhe, why ‘tis impoſſible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Why hee's a deuill, a deuill, a very fiend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſhe's a deuill, a deuill, the deuils damme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, ſhe's a Lambe, a Doue, a foole to him:
Ile tell you ſir Lucentio; when the Priest
Should aske if Katherine ſhould be his wife,
I, by goggs woones quoth he, and ſwore ſo loud,
That all amaz’d the Priest let fall the booke,
And as he ſtoop’d againe to take it vp,
This mad-brain’d bridegroome tooke him ſuch a cuffe,
That downe fell Priest and booke, and booke and Priest,
Now take them vp quoth he, if any list.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaid the wench when he rose againe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Trembled and ſhooke: for why, he ſtamp’d and ſwore, as if the Vicar meant to cozen him: but after ma-ny ceremonies done, hee calls for wine, a health quoth he, as if he had beene aboord carowsing to his Mates af-ter a ſtorme, quaft off the Muscadell, and threw the ſops all in the Sextons face: hauing no other reason, but that his beard grew thinne and hungerly, and ſeem’d to aske him ſops as hee was drinking: This done, hee tooke the Bride about the necke, and kist her lips with ſuch a cla-morous ſmacke, that at the parting all the Church did eccho: and I ſeeing this, came thence for very ſhame, and after mee I know the rout is comming, ſuch a mad mar-ryage neuer was before: harke, harke, I heare the min-strels play. Musicke playes.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Petruchio, Kate, Bianca, Hortensio, Baptista.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentlemen & friends, I thank you for your pains,
I know you thinke to dine with me to day,
And haue prepar’d great ſtore of wedding cheere,
But ſo it is, my haste doth call me hence,
And therefore heere I meane to take my leaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Is't poſſible you will away to night?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: I must away to day before night come,
Make it no wonder: if you knew my busineſſe,
You would intreat me rather goe then ſtay:
