And honeſt company, I thanke you all,
That haue beheld me giue away my ſelfe
To this mo’t patient, ſweet, and vertuous wife,
Dine with my father, drinke a health to me,
For I must hence, and farewell to you all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs intreat you ſtay till after dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: It may not be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me intreat you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: It cannot be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me intreat you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: I am content.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you content to ſtay?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: I am content you ſhall entreat me ſtay,
But yet not ſtay, entreat me how you can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: Now if you loue me ſtay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Grumio, my horse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir, they be ready, the Oates haue eaten the horses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then,
Doe what thou canst, I will not goe to day,
No, nor to morrow, not till I please my ſelfe,
The dore is open ſir, there lies your way,
You may be iogging whiles your bootes are greene:
For me, Ile not be gone till I please my ſelfe,
‘Tis like you'll proue a iolly ſurly groome,
That take it on you at the first ſo roundly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: O Kate content thee, prethee be not angry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: I will be angry, what hast thou to doe?
Father, be quiet, he ſhall ſtay my leisure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: I marry ſir, now it begins to worke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentlemen, forward to the bridall dinner,
I ſee a woman may be made a foole
If ſhe had not a ſpirit to resist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſhall goe forward Kate at thy command,
Obey the Bride you that attend on her.
Goe to the feast, reuell and domineere,
Carowse full measure to her maiden-head,
Be madde and merry, or goe hang your ſelues:
But for my bonny Kate, ſhe must with me:
Nay, looke not big, nor ſtampe, not ſtare, nor fret,
I will be master of what is mine owne,
Shee is my goods, my chattels, ſhe is my house,
My houshold-stuffe, my field, my barne,
My horse, my oxe, my aſſe, my any thing,
And heere ſhe ſtands, touch her who euer dare,
Ile bring mine action on the proudest he
That ſtops my way in Padua: Grumio
Draw forth thy weapon, we are beset with theeues,
Rescue thy Mistreſſe if thou be a man:
Feare not ſweet wench, they ſhall not touch thee Kate,
Ile buckler thee against a Million.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, let them goe, a couple of quiet ones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Went they not quickly, I ſhould die with laughing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Of all mad matches neuer was the like.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistreſſe, what’s your opinion of your ſister?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: That being mad her ſelfe, ſhe's madly mated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: I warrant him Petruchio is Kated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Neighbours and friends, though Bride & Bridegroom wants
For to ſupply the places at the table,
You know there wants no iunkets at the feast:
Lucentio, you ſhall ſupply the Bridegroomes place,
And let Bianca take her ſisters roome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall ſweet Bianca practise how to bride it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: She ſhall Lucentio: come gentlemen lets goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, fie on all tired Iades, on all mad Masters, & all foule waies: was euer man ſo beaten? was euer man ſo raide? was euer man ſo weary? I am ſent before to make a fire, and they are comming after to warme them: now were not I a little pot, & ſoone hot; my very lippes might freeze to my teeth, my tongue to the roofe of my mouth, my heart in my belly, ere I ſhould come by a fire to thaw me, but I with blowing the fire ſhall warme my ſelfe: for considering the weather, a taller man then I will take cold: Holla, hoa Curtis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Curt.
SPEECH.LINE: Who is that calls ſo coldly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: A piece of Ice: if thou doubt it, thou maist ſlide from my ſhoulder to my heele, with no greater a run but my head and my necke. A fire good Curtis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: Is my master and his wife comming Grumio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh I Curtis I, and therefore fire, fire, cast on no water.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: Is ſhe ſo hot a ſhrew as ſhe's reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: She was good Curtis before this frost: but thou know'st winter tames man, woman, and beast: for it hath tam’d my old master, and my new mistris, and my ſelfe fellow Curtis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Away you three inch foole, I am no beast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Am I but three inches? Why thy horne is a foot and ſo long am I at the least. But wilt thou make a fire, or ſhall I complaine on thee to our mistris, whose hand (she being now at hand) thou ſhalt ſoone feele, to thy cold comfort, for being ſlow in thy hot office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: I prethee good Grumio, tell me, how goes the world?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: A cold world Curtis in euery office but thine, & therefore fire: do thy duty, and haue thy dutie, for my Master and mistris are almost frozen to death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: There's fire readie, and therefore good Grumio the newes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Iacke boy, ho boy, and as much newes as wilt thou.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, you are ſo full of conicatching.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Why therefore fire, for I haue caught extreme cold. Where's the Cooke, is ſupper ready, the house trim’d, rushes ſtrew’d, cobwebs ſwept, the ſeruingmen in their new fustian, the white ſtockings, and euery offi-cer his wedding garment on? Be the Iackes faire with-in, the Gils faire without, the Carpets laide, and euerie thing in order?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: All readie: and therefore I pray thee newes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: First know my horse is tired, my master & mi-stris falne out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: How?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Out of their ſaddles into the durt, and thereby hangs a tale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's ha't good Grumio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Lend thine eare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: There.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: This ‘tis to feele a tale, not to heare a tale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: And therefore ‘tis cal’d a ſensible tale: and this Cuffe was but to knocke at your eare, and beseech list-ning: now I begin, Inprimis wee came downe a fowle hill, my Master riding behinde my Mistris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: Both of one horse?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: What's that to thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: Why a horse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell thou the tale: but hadst thou not crost me, thou ſhouldst haue heard how her horse fel, and ſhe vn-der her horse: thou ſhouldst haue heard in how miery a place, how ſhe was bemoil’d, how hee left her with the horse vpon her, how he beat me because her horse ſtum-bled, how ſhe waded through the durt to plucke him off me: how he ſwore, how ſhe prai’d, that neuer prai’d be-fore: how I cried, how the horses ranne away, how her bridle was burst: how I lost my crupper, with manie things of worthy memorie, which now ſhall die in obli-uion, and thou returne vnexperienc’d to thy graue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: By this reckning he is more ſhrew than ſhe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and that thou and the proudest of you all ſhall finde when he comes home. But what talke I of this? Call forth Nathaniel, Ioseph, Nicholas, Phillip, Walter, Su-gersop and the rest: let their heads bee ſlickely comb’d, their blew coats brush’d, and their garters of an indiffe-rent knit, let them curtsie with their left legges, and not presume to touch a haire of my Masters horse-taile, till they kiſſe their hands. Are they all readie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: They are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Call them forth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you heare ho? you must meete my maister to countenance my mistris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſhe hath a face of her owne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: Who knowes not that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou it ſeemes, that cals for company to coun-tenance her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: I call them forth to credit her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſhe comes to borrow nothing of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nat.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome home Grumio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phil.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Grumio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ios.
SPEECH.LINE: What Grumio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nick.
SPEECH.LINE: Fellow Grumio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nat.
SPEECH.LINE: How now old lad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome you: how now you: what you: fel-low you: and thus much for greeting. Now my ſpruce companions, is all readie, and all things neate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nat.
SPEECH.LINE: All things is readie, how neere is our master?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: E'ne at hand, alighted by this: and therefore be not— Cockes paſſion, ſilence, I heare my master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Where be these knaues? What no man at doore
To hold my ſtirrop, nor to take my horse?
Where is Nathaniel, Gregory, Phillip.
All ſer.
Heere, heere ſir, heere ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere ſir, heere ſir, heere ſir, heere ſir.
You logger-headed and vnpollisht groomes:
What? no attendance? no regard? no dutie?
Where is the foolish knaue I ſent before?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere ſir, as foolish as I was before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: You pezant, ſwain, you horson malt-horse drudg
Did I not bid thee meete me in the Parke,
And bring along these rascal knaues with thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grumio.
SPEECH.LINE: Nathaniels coate ſir was not fully made,
And Gabrels pumpes were all vnpinkt i'th heele:
There was no Linke to colour Peters hat,
And Walters dagger was not come from ſheathing:
There were none fine, but Adam, Rafe, and Gregory,
The rest were ragged, old, and beggerly,
Yet as they are, heere are they come to meete you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet
SPEECH.LINE: Go rascals, go, and fetch my ſupper in. Ex. Ser.
Where is the life that late I led?
Where are those? Sit downe Kate,
And welcome. Soud, ſoud, ſoud, ſoud.
Why when I ſay? Nay good ſweete Kate be merrie.
Off with my boots, you rogues: you villaines, when?
It was the Friar of Orders gray,
As he forth walked on his way.
Out you rogue, you plucke my foote awrie,
Take that, and mend the plucking of the other.
Be merrie Kate: Some water heere: what hoa.
Where's my Spaniel Troilus? Sirra, get you hence,
And bid my cozen Ferdinand come hither:
One Kate that you must kiſſe, and be acquainted with.
Where are my Slippers? Shall I haue ſome water?
Come Kate and wash, & welcome heartily:
You horson villaine, will you let it fall?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Patience I pray you, 'twas a fault vnwilling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: A horson beetle-headed flap-ear’d knaue:
Come Kate ſit downe, I know you haue a ſtomacke,
Will you giue thankes, ſweete Kate, or else ſhall I?
What's this, Mutton?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Who brought it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peter.
SPEECH.LINE: I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis burnt, and ſo is all the meate:
What dogges are these? Where is the rascall Cooke?
How durst you villaines bring it from the dreſſer
And ſerue it thus to me that loue it not?
There, take it to you, trenchers, cups, and all:
You heedleſſe iolt-heads, and vnmanner’d ſlaues.
What, do you grumble? Ile be with you ſtraight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you husband be not ſo disquiet,
The meate was well, if you were ſo contented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: I tell thee Kate, 'twas burnt and dried away,
And I expreſſely am forbid to touch it:
For it engenders choller, planteth anger,
And better 'twere that both of vs did fast,
Since of our ſelues, our ſelues are chollericke,
Then feede it with ſuch ouer-rosted flesh:
Be patient, to morrow't ſhalbe mended,
And for this night we'l fast for companie.
Come I wil bring thee to thy Bridall chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nath.
SPEECH.LINE: Peter didst euer ſee the like.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peter.
SPEECH.LINE: He kils her in her owne humor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grumio.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: In her chamber, making a ſermon of continen-cie to her, and railes, and ſweares, and rates, that ſhee (poore ſoule) knowes not which way to ſtand, to looke, to ſpeake, and ſits as one new risen from a dreame. A-way, away, for he is comming hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus haue I politickely begun my reigne,
And ‘tis my hope to end ſucceſſefully:
My Faulcon now is ſharpe, and paſſing emptie,
And til ſhe ſtoope, ſhe must not be full gorg’d,
For then ſhe neuer lookes vpon her lure.
Another way I haue to man my Haggard,
To make her come, and know her Keepers call:
That is, to watch her, as we watch these Kites,
That baite, and beate, and will not be obedient:
She eate no meate to day, nor none ſhall eate.
Last night ſhe ſlept not, nor to night ſhe ſhall not:
As with the meate, ſome vndeserued fault
Ile finde about the making of the bed,
And heere Ile fling the pillow, there the boulster,
This way the Couerlet, another way the ſheets:
I, and amid this hurlie I intend,
That all is done in reuerend care of her,
And in conclusion, ſhe ſhal watch all night,
And if ſhe chance to nod, Ile raile and brawle,
And with the clamor keepe her ſtil awake:
This is a way to kil a Wife with kindneſſe,
And thus Ile curbe her mad and headstrong humor:
He that knowes better how to tame a ſhrew,
Now let him ſpeake, ‘tis charity to ſhew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Is't poſſible friend Lisio, that mistris Bianca
Doth fancie any other but Lucentio,
I tel you ſir, ſhe beares me faire in hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, to ſatisfie you in what I haue ſaid,
Stand by, and marke the manner of his teaching.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Mistris, profit you in what you reade?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: What Master reade you first, resolue me that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: I reade, that I profeſſe the Art to loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: And may you proue ſir Master of your Art.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: While you ſweet deere proue Mistreſſe of my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Quicke proceeders marry, now tel me I pray, you that durst ſweare that your Mistris Bianca Lou’d me in the World ſo wel as Lucentio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh despightful Loue, vnconstant womankind,
I tel thee Lisio this is wonderfull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistake no more, I am not Lisio,
Nor a Musitian as I ſeeme to bee,
But one that ſcorne to liue in this disguise,
For ſuch a one as leaues a Gentleman,
And makes a God of ſuch a Cullion;
Know ſir, that I am cal’d Hortensio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Signior Hortensio, I haue often heard
Of your entire affection to Bianca,
And ſince mine eyes are witneſſe of her lightneſſe,
I wil with you, if you be ſo contented,
Forsweare Bianca, and her loue for euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: See how they kiſſe and court: Signior Lucentio,
Heere is my hand, and heere I firmly vow
Neuer to woo her more, but do forsweare her
As one vnworthie all the former fauours
That I haue fondly flatter’d them withall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: And heere I take the like vnfained oath,
Neuer to marrie with her, though ſhe would intreate,
Fie on her, ſee how beastly ſhe doth court him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Would all the world but he had quite forsworn
For me, that I may ſurely keepe mine oath.
I wil be married to a wealthy Widdow,
Ere three dayes paſſe, which hath as long lou’d me,
As I haue lou’d this proud disdainful Haggard,
And ſo farewel ſignior Lucentio,
Kindneſſe in women, not their beauteous lookes
Shal win my loue, and ſo I take my leaue,
In resolution, as I ſwore before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris Bianca, bleſſe you with ſuch grace,
As longeth to a Louers bleſſed case:
Nay, I haue tane you napping gentle Loue,
And haue forsworne you with Hortensio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: Tranio you iest, but haue you both forsworne mee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris we haue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Then we are rid of Lisio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: I'faith hee'l haue a lustie Widdow now,
That ſhalbe woo’d, and wedded in a day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: God giue him ioy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and hee'l tame her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bianca.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſayes ſo Tranio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith he is gone vnto the taming ſchoole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: The taming ſchoole: what is there ſuch a place?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: I mistris, and Petruchio is the master,
That teacheth trickes eleuen and twentie long,
To tame a ſhrew, and charme her chattering tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Master, master I haue watcht ſo long,
That I am dogge-wearie, but at last I ſpied
An ancient Angel comming downe the hill,
Wil ſerue the turne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: What is he Biondello?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bio.
SPEECH.LINE: Master, a Marcantant, or a pedant,
I know not what, but formall in apparrell,
In gate and countenance ſurely like a Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: And what of him Tranio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: If he be credulous, and trust my tale,
Ile make him glad to ſeeme Vincentio,
And giue aſſurance to Baptista Minola.
As if he were the right Vincentio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Take me your loue, and then let me alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: God ſaue you ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: And you ſir, you are welcome,
Trauaile you farre on, or are you at the farthest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir at the farthest for a weeke or two,
But then vp farther, and as farre as Rome,
And ſo to Tripolie, if God lend me life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: What Countreyman I pray?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Of Mantua.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Of Mantua Sir, marrie God forbid,
And come to Padua careleſſe of your life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: My life ſir? how I pray? for that goes hard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis death for any one in Mantua
To come to Padua, know you not the cause?
Your ſhips are ſtaid at Venice, and the Duke
For priuate quarrel 'twixt your Duke and him,
Hath publish’d and proclaim’d it openly:
‘Tis meruaile, but that you are but newly come,
You might haue heard it else proclaim’d about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas ſir, it is worse for me then ſo,
For I haue bils for monie by exchange
From Florence, and must heere deliuer them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Wel ſir, to do you courtesie,
This wil I do, and this I wil aduise you.
First tell me, haue you euer beene at Pisa?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir, in Pisa haue I often bin,
Pisa renowned for graue Citizens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Among them know you one Vincentio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: I know him not, but I haue heard of him:
A Merchant of incomparable wealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: He is my father ſir, and ſooth to ſay,
In count'nance ſomewhat doth resemble you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: As much as an apple doth an oyster, & all one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: To ſaue your life in this extremitie,
This fauor wil I do you for his ſake,
And thinke it not the worst of all your fortunes,
That you are like to Sir Vincentio.
His name and credite ſhal you vndertake,
And in my house you ſhal be friendly lodg’d,
Looke that you take vpon you as you ſhould,
You vnderstand me ſir: ſo ſhal you ſtay
Til you haue done your busineſſe in the Citie:
If this be court'sie ſir, accept of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ſir I do, and wil repute you euer
The patron of my life and libertie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Then go with me, to make the matter good,
This by the way I let you vnderstand,
My father is heere look’d for euerie day,
To paſſe aſſurance of a dowre in marriage
'Twixt me, and one Baptistas daughter heere:
In all these circumstances Ile instruct you,
Go with me to cloath you as becomes you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no forsooth I dare not for my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ka.
SPEECH.LINE: The more my wrong, the more his ſpite appears.
What, did he marrie me to famish me?
Beggers that come vnto my fathers doore,
Vpon intreatie haue a present almes,
If not, elsewhere they meete with charitie:
But I, who neuer knew how to intreat,
Nor neuer needed that I ſhould intreate,
Am ſtaru’d for meate, giddie for lacke of ſleepe:
With oathes kept waking, and with brawling fed,
And that which ſpights me more then all these wants,
He does it vnder name of perfect loue:
As who ſhould ſay, if I ſhould ſleepe or eate
'Twere deadly ſickneſſe, or else present death.
I prethee go, and get me ſome repast,
I care not what, ſo it be holsome foode.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſay you to a Neats foote?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis paſſing good, I prethee let me haue it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: I feare it is too chollericke a meate.
How ſay you to a fat Tripe finely broyl’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: I like it well, good Grumio fetch it me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot tell, I feare ‘tis chollericke.
What ſay you to a peece of Beefe and Mustard?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: A dish that I do loue to feede vpon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but the Mustard is too hot a little.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then the Beefe, and let the Mustard rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then I wil not, you ſhal haue the Mustard
Or else you get no beefe of Grumio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Then both or one, or any thing thou wilt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then the Mustard without the beefe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Go get thee gone, thou false deluding ſlaue,
That feed'st me with the verie name of meate.
Sorrow on thee, and all the packe of you
That triumph thus vpon my misery:
Go get thee gone, I ſay.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Petruchio, and Hortensio with meate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: How fares my Kate, what ſweeting all a-mort?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris, what cheere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith as cold as can be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Plucke vp thy ſpirits, looke cheerfully vpon me.
Heere Loue, thou ſeest how diligent I am,
To dreſſe thy meate my ſelfe, and bring it thee.
I am ſure ſweet Kate, this kindneſſe merites thankes.
What, not a word? Nay then, thou lou'st it not:
And all my paines is ſorted to no proofe.
Heere take away this dish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you let it ſtand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: The poorest ſeruice is repaide with thankes,
And ſo ſhall mine before you touch the meate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Signior Petruchio, fie you are too blame:
Come Mistris Kate, Ile beare you companie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Eate it vp all Hortensio, if thou louest mee:
Much good do it vnto thy gentle heart:
Kate eate apace; and now my honie Loue,
Will we returne vnto thy Fathers house,
And reuell it as brauely as the best,
With ſilken coats and caps, and golden Rings,
With Ruffes and Cuffes, and Fardingales, and things:
With Scarfes, and Fannes, & double change of brau'ry,
With Amber Bracelets, Beades, and all this knau'ry.
What hast thou din’d? The Tailor ſtaies thy leasure,
To decke thy bodie with his ruffling treasure.
Come Tailor, let vs ſee these ornaments.
Lay forth the gowne. What newes with you ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fel.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere is the cap your Worship did bespeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Why this was moulded on a porrenger,
A Veluet dish: Fie, fie, ‘tis lewd and filthy,
Why ‘tis a cockle or a walnut-shell,
A knacke, a toy, a tricke, a babies cap:
Away with it, come let me haue a bigger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile haue no bigger, this doth fit the time,
And Gentlewomen weare ſuch caps as these.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: When you are gentle, you ſhall haue one too,
And not till then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: That will not be in hast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir I trust I may haue leaue to ſpeake,
And ſpeake I will. I am no childe, no babe,
Your betters haue indur’d me ſay my minde,
And if you cannot, best you ſtop your eares.
My tongue will tell the anger of my heart,
Or els my heart concealing it wil breake,
And rather then it ſhall, I will be free,
Euen to the vttermost as I please in words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Why thou ſaist true, it is paltrie cap,
A custard coffen, a bauble, a ſilken pie,
I loue thee well in that thou lik'st it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Loue me, or loue me not, I like the cap,
And it I will haue, or I will haue none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy gowne, why I: come Tailor let vs ſee't.
Oh mercie God, what masking ſtuffe is heere?
Whats this? a ſleeue? ‘tis like demi cannon,
What, vp and downe caru’d like an apple Tart?
Heers ſnip, and nip, and cut, and ſlish and ſlash,
Like to a Censor in a barbers ſhoppe:
Why what a deuils name Tailor cal'st thou this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſee ſhees like to haue neither cap nor gowne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tai.
SPEECH.LINE: You bid me make it orderlie and well,
According to the fashion, and the time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie and did: but if you be remembred,
I did not bid you marre it to the time.
Go hop me ouer euery kennell home,
For you ſhall hop without my custome ſir:
Ile none of it; hence, make your best of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: I neuer ſaw a better fashion’d gowne,
More queint, more pleasing, nor more commendable:
Belike you meane to make a puppet of me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Why true, he meanes to make a puppet of thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tail.
SPEECH.LINE: She ſaies your Worship meanes to make a puppet of her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh monstrous arrogance:
Thou lyest, thou thred, thou thimble,
Thou yard three quarters, halfe yard, quarter, naile,
Thou Flea, thou Nit, thou winter cricket thou:
Brau’d in mine owne house with a ſkeine of thred:
Away thou Ragge, thou quantitie, thou remnant,
Or I ſhall ſo be-mete thee with thy yard,
As thou ſhalt thinke on prating whil'st thou liu'st:
I tell thee I, that thou hast marr’d her gowne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tail.
SPEECH.LINE: Your worship is deceiu’d, the gowne is made
Iust as my master had direction:
Grumio gaue order how it ſhould be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: I gaue him no order, I gaue him the ſtuffe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tail.
SPEECH.LINE: But how did you desire it ſhould be made?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie ſir with needle and thred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tail.
SPEECH.LINE: But did you not request to haue it cut?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast fac’d many things.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tail.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Face not mee: thou hast brau’d manie men, braue not me; I will neither bee fac’d nor brau’d. I ſay vnto thee, I bid thy Master cut out the gowne, but I did not bid him cut it to peeces. Ergo thou liest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tail.
SPEECH.LINE: Why heere is the note of the fashion to testify.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Reade it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: The note lies in's throate if he ſay I ſaid ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tail.
SPEECH.LINE: Inprimis, a loose bodied gowne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Master, if euer I ſaid loose-bodied gowne, ſow me in the ſkirts of it, and beate me to death with a bot-tome of browne thred: I ſaid a gowne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Proceede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tai.
SPEECH.LINE: With a ſmall compast cape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: I confeſſe the cape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tai.
SPEECH.LINE: With a trunke ſleeue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: I confeſſe two ſleeues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tai.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſleeues curiously cut.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: I there's the villanie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Error i'th bill ſir, error i'th bill? I commanded the ſleeues ſhould be cut out, and ſow’d vp againe, and that Ile proue vpon thee, though thy little finger be ar-med in a thimble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tail.
SPEECH.LINE: This is true that I ſay, and I had thee in place where thou ſhouldst know it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: I am for thee ſtraight: take thou the bill, giue me thy meat-yard, and ſpare not me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: God-a-mercie Grumio, then hee ſhall haue no oddes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſir in breefe the gowne is not for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: You are i'th right ſir, ‘tis for my mistris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Go take it vp vnto thy masters vse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Villaine, not for thy life: Take vp my Mistreſſe gowne for thy masters vse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, what’s your conceit in that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gru.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ſir, the conceit is deeper then you think for:
Take vp my Mistris gowne to his masters vse.
Oh fie, fie, fie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Hortensio, ſay thou wilt ſee the Tailor paide:
Go take it hence, be gone, and ſay no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Tailor, Ile pay thee for thy gowne to morrow,
Take no vnkindneſſe of his hastie words:
Away I ſay, commend me to thy master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, come my Kate, we will vnto your fathers,
Euen in these honeſt meane habiliments:
Our purses ſhall be proud, our garments poore:
For ‘tis the minde that makes the bodie rich.
And as the Sunne breakes through the darkest clouds,
So honor peereth in the meanest habit.
What is the Iay more precious then the Larke?
Because his feathers are more beautifull.
Or is the Adder better then the Eele,
Because his painted ſkin contents the eye.
Oh no good Kate: neither art thou the worse
For this poore furniture, and meane array.
If thou accountedst it ſhame, lay it on me,
And therefore frolicke, we will hence forthwith,
To feast and ſport vs at thy fathers house,
Go call my men, and let vs ſtraight to him,
And bring our horses vnto Long-lane end,
There wil we mount, and thither walke on foote,
Let's ſee, I thinke ‘tis now ſome ſeuen a clocke,
And well we may come there by dinner time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: I dare aſſure you ſir, ‘tis almost two,
And 'twill be ſupper time ere you come there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſhall be ſeuen ere I go to horse:
Looke what I ſpeake, or do, or thinke to doe,
You are ſtill croſſing it, ſirs let't alone,
I will not goe to day, and ere I doe,
It ſhall be what a clock I ſay it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſo this gallant will command the ſunne.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Tranio, and the Pedant drest like Vincentio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirs, this is the house, please it you that I call.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: I what else, and but I be deceiued,
Signior Baptista may remember me
Neere twentie yeares a goe in Genoa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Where we were lodgers, at the Pegasus,
Tis well, and hold your owne in any case
With ſuch austeritie as longeth to a father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: I warrant you: but ſir here comes your boy,
'Twere good he were ſchool’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Feare you not him: ſirra Biondello,
Now doe your dutie throughlie I aduise you:
Imagine 'twere the right Vincentio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, feare not me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: But hast thou done thy errand to Baptista.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: I told him that your father was at Venice,
And that you look't for him this day in Padua,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Th'art a tall fellow, hold thee that to drinke, Here comes Baptista: ſet your countenance ſir.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Baptista and Lucentio: Pedant booted and bare headed

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Signior Baptista you are happilie met:
Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of,
I pray you ſtand good father to me now,
Giue me Bianca for my patrimony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Soft ſon: ſir by your leaue, hauing com to Padua
To gather in ſome debts, my ſon Lucentio
Made me acquainted with a waighty cause
Of loue betweene your daughter and himselfe:
And for the good report I heare of you,
And for the loue he beareth to your daughter,
And ſhe to him: to ſtay him not too long,
I am content in a good fathers care
To haue him matcht, and if you please to like
No worse then I, vpon ſome agreement
Me ſhall you finde readie and willing
With one consent to haue her ſo bestowed:
For curious I cannot be with you
Signior Baptista, of whom I heare ſo well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, pardon me in what I haue to ſay,
Your plainneſſe and your ſhortneſſe please me well:
Right true it is your ſonne Lucentio here
Doth loue my daughter, and ſhe loueth him,
Or both diſſemble deepely their affections:
And therefore if you ſay no more then this,
That like a Father you will deale with him,
And paſſe my daughter a ſufficient dower,
The match is made, and all is done,
Your ſonne ſhall haue my daughter with consent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you ſir, where then doe you know best
We be affied and ſuch aſſurance tane,
As ſhall with either parts agreement ſtand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Not in my house Lucentio, for you know
Pitchers haue eares, and I haue manie ſeruants,
Besides old Gremio is harkning ſtill,
And happilie we might be interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Then at my lodging, and it like you,
There doth my father lie: and there this night
Weele paſſe the busineſſe priuately and well:
Send for your daughter by your ſeruant here,
My Boy ſhall fetch the Scriuener presentlie,
The worst is this that at ſo ſlender warning,
You are like to haue a thin and ſlender pittance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: It likes me well: Cambio hie you home, and bid Bianca make her readie ſtraight: And if you will tell what hath hapned, Lucentios Father is arriued in Padua, And how ſhe's like to be Lucentios wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Biond.
SPEECH.LINE: I praie the gods ſhe may withall my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tran.
SPEECH.LINE: Dallie not with the gods, but get thee gone.
Signior Baptista, ſhall I leade the way,
Welcome, one meſſe is like to be your cheere,
Come ſir, we will better it in Pisa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap
SPEECH.LINE: I follow you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: Cambio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaist thou Biondello.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Biond.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſaw my Master winke and laugh vpon you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Biondello, what of that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Biond.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith nothing: but has left mee here behinde to expound the meaning or morrall of his ſignes and to-kens. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray thee moralize them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Biond.
SPEECH.LINE: Then thus: Baptista is ſafe talking with the deceiuing Father of a deceitfull ſonne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: And what of him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Biond.
SPEECH.LINE: His daughter is to be brought by you to the ſupper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: And then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bio.
SPEECH.LINE: The old Priest at Saint Lukes Church is at your command at all houres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: And what of all this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot tell, expect they are busied about a counterfeit aſſurance: take you aſſurance of her, Cum preuilegio ad Impremendum ſolem, to th’ Church take the Priest, Clarke, and ſome ſufficient honeſt witneſſes: If this be not that you looke for, I haue no more to ſay, But bid Bianca farewell for euer and a day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Hear'st thou Biondello.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Biond.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot tarry: I knew a wench maried in an afternoone as ſhee went to the Garden for Parseley to ſtuffe a Rabit, and ſo may you ſir: and ſo adew ſir, my Master hath appointed me to goe to Saint Lukes to bid the Priest be readie to come against you come with your appendix.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I may and will, if ſhe be ſo contented:
She will be pleas’d, then wherefore ſhould I doubt:
Hap what hap may, Ile roundly goe about her:
It ſhall goe hard if Cambio goe without her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on a Gods name, once more toward our fathers: Good Lord how bright and goodly ſhines the Moone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: The Moone, the Sunne: it is not Moonelight now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay it is the Moone that ſhines ſo bright.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: I know it is the Sunne that ſhines ſo bright.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Now by my mothers ſonne, and that’s my ſelfe,
It ſhall be moone, or ſtarre, or what I list,
Or ere I iourney to your Fathers house:
Goe on, and fetch our horses backe againe,
Euermore crost and crost, nothing but crost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: Say as he ſaies, or we ſhall neuer goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Forward I pray, ſince we haue come ſo farre,
And be it moone, or ſunne, or what you please:
And if you please to call it a rush Candle,
Henceforth I vowe it ſhall be ſo for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay it is the Moone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: I know it is the Moone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then you lye: it is the bleſſed Sunne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Then God be blest, it is the bleſſed ſun,
But ſunne it is not, when you ſay it is not,
And the Moone changes euen as your minde:
What you will haue it nam’d, euen that it is,
And ſo it ſhall be ſo for Katherine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: Petruchio, goe thy waies, the field is won.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, forward, forward, thus the bowle ſhould run,
And not vnluckily against the Bias:
But ſoft, Company is comming here.
Good morrow gentle Mistris, where away:
Tell me ſweete Kate, and tell me truely too,
Hast thou beheld a fresher Gentlewoman:
Such warre of white and red within her cheekes:
What ſtars do ſpangle heauen with ſuch beautie,
As those two eyes become that heauenly face?
Faire louely Maide, once more good day to thee:
Sweete Kate embrace her for her beauties ſake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: A will make the man mad to make the woman of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Yong budding Virgin, faire, and fresh, & ſweet,
Whether away, or whether is thy aboade?
Happy the Parents of ſo faire a childe;
Happier the man whom fauourable ſtars
A lots thee for his louely bedfellow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Why how now Kate, I hope thou art not mad,
This is a man old, wrinckled, faded, withered,
And not a Maiden, as thou ſaist he is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon old father my mistaking eies,
That haue bin ſo bedazled with the ſunne,
That euery thing I looke on ſeemeth greene:
Now I perceiue thou art a reuerent Father:
Pardon I pray thee for my mad mistaking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Do good old grandsire, & withall make known
Which way thou trauellest, if along with vs,
We ſhall be ioyfull of thy companie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vin.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire Sir, and you my merry Mistris,
That with your ſtrange encounter much amasde me:
My name is call’d Vincentio, my dwelling Pisa,
And bound I am to Padua, there to visite
A ſonne of mine, which long I haue not ſeene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: What is his name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vinc.
SPEECH.LINE: Lucentio gentle ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Happily met, the happier for thy ſonne:
And now by Law, as well as reuerent age,
I may intitle thee my louing Father,
The ſister to my wife, this Gentlewoman,
Thy Sonne by this hath married: wonder not,
Nor be not grieued, ſhe is of good esteeme,
Her dowrie wealthie, and of worthie birth;
Beside, ſo qualified, as may beseeme
The Spouse of any noble Gentleman:
Let me imbrace with old Vincentio,
And wander we to ſee thy honeſt ſonne,
Who will of thy arriuall be full ioyous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vinc.
SPEECH.LINE: But is this true, or is it else your pleasure,
Like pleasant trauailors to breake a Iest
Vpon the companie you ouertake?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe aſſure thee father ſo it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Come goe along and ſee the truth hereof,
For our first merriment hath made thee iealous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Well Petruchio, this has put me in heart; Haue to my Widdow, and if ſhe froward, Then hast thou taught Hortentio to be vntoward.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Biondello, Lucentio and Bianca, Gremio is out before

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Biond.
SPEECH.LINE: Softly and ſwiftly ſir, for the Priest is ready.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I flie Biondello; but they may chance to neede thee at home, therefore leaue vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Biond.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay faith, Ile ſee the Church a your backe, and then come backe to my mistris as ſoone as I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: I maruaile Cambio comes not all this while.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Petruchio, Kate, Vincentio, Grumio with Attendants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir heres the doore, this is Lucentios house,
My Fathers beares more toward the Market-place,
Thither must I, and here I leaue you ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vin.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall not choose but drinke before you go,
I thinke I ſhall command your welcome here;
And by all likelihood ſome cheere is toward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grem.
SPEECH.LINE: They're busie within, you were best knocke lowder.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Pedant lookes out of the window.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: What's he that knockes as he would beat downe the gate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vin.
SPEECH.LINE: Is Signior Lucentio within ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: He's within ſir, but not to be ſpoken withall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vinc.
SPEECH.LINE: What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two to make merrie withall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Keepe your hundred pounds to your ſelfe, hee ſhall neede none ſo long as I liue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I told you your ſonne was well beloued in Padua: doe you heare ſir, to leaue friuolous circumstan-ces, I pray you tell ſignior Lucentio that his Father is come from Pisa, and is here at the doore to ſpeake with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou liest his Father is come from Padua, and here looking out at the window.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vin.
SPEECH.LINE: Art thou his father?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir, ſo his mother ſaies, if I may beleeue her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Why how now gentleman: why this is flat kna-uerie to take vpon you another mans name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Lay hands on the villaine, I beleeue a meanes to cosen ſome bodie in this Citie vnder my countenance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bio.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue ſeene them in the Church together, God ſend 'em good ſhipping: but who is here? mine old Ma-ster Vincentio: now wee are vndone and brought to no-thing. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vin.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither crackhempe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope I may choose Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vin.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither you rogue, what haue you forgot mee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Biond.
SPEECH.LINE: Forgot you, no ſir: I could not forget you, for
I neuer ſaw you before in all my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vinc.
SPEECH.LINE: What, you notorious villaine, didst thou neuer ſee thy Mistris father, Vincentio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: What my old worshipfull old master? yes marie ſir ſee where he lookes out of the window.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vin
SPEECH.LINE: Ist ſo indeede. He beates Biondello.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: Helpe, helpe, helpe, here's a mad man will mur-der me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedan.
SPEECH.LINE: Helpe, ſonne, helpe ſignior Baptista.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Preethe Kate let's ſtand aside and ſee the end of this controuersie.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Pedant with ſeruants, Baptista, Tranio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, what are you that offer to beate my ſer-uant?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vinc.
SPEECH.LINE: What am I ſir: nay what are you ſir: oh immor-tall Goddes: oh fine villaine, a ſilken doublet, a vel-uet hose, a ſcarlet cloake, and a copataine hat: oh I am vndone, I am vndone: while I plaie the good husband at home, my ſonne and my ſeruant ſpend all at the vni-uersitie. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, what’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bapt.
SPEECH.LINE: What is the man lunaticke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, you ſeeme a ſober ancient Gentleman by your habit: but your words ſhew you a mad man: why ſir, what cernes it you, if I weare Pearle and gold: I thank my good Father, I am able to maintaine it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vin.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy father: oh villaine, he is a Saile-maker in
Bergamo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: You mistake ſir, you mistake ſir, praie what do you thinke is his name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vin.
SPEECH.LINE: His name, as if I knew not his name: I haue brought him vp euer ſince he was three yeeres old, and his name is Tronio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Awaie, awaie mad aſſe, his name is Lucentio, and he is mine onelie ſonne and heire to the Lands of me ſig-nior Vincentio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ven.
SPEECH.LINE: Lucentio: oh he hath murdred his Master; laie hold on him I charge you in the Dukes name: oh my ſonne, my ſonne: tell me thou villaine, where is my ſon Lucentio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Call forth an officer: Carrie this mad knaue to the Iaile: father Baptista, I charge you ſee that hee be forth comming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vinc.
SPEECH.LINE: Carrie me to the Iaile?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Staie officer, he ſhall not go to prison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Talke not ſignior Gremio: I ſaie he ſhall goe to prison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Take heede ſignior Baptista, least you be coni-catcht in this busineſſe: I dare ſweare this is the right Vincentio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweare if thou dar'st.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Naie, I dare not ſweare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tran.
SPEECH.LINE: Then thou wert best ſaie that I am not Lu-centio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, I know thee to be ſignior Lucentio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Awaie with the dotard, to the Iaile with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vin.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus ſtrangers may be haild and abusd: oh mon-strous villaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh we are ſpoil’d, and yonder he is, denie him, forsweare him, or else we are all vndone.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exit Biondello, Tranio and Pedant as fast as may be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon ſweete father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vin.
SPEECH.LINE: Liues my ſweete ſonne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon deere father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: How hast thou offended, where is Lucentio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Here's Lucentio, right ſonne to the right Vin-centio,
That haue by marriage made thy daughter mine,
While counterfeit ſupposes bleer’d thine eine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Here's packing with a witneſſe to deceiue vs all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vin.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is that damned villaine Tranio,
That fac’d and braued me in this matter ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, tell me is not this my Cambio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: Cambio is chang’d into Lucentio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Loue wrought these miracles. Biancas loue
Made me exchange my ſtate with Tranio,
While he did beare my countenance in the towne,
And happilie I haue arriued at the last
Vnto the wished hauen of my bliſſe:
What Tranio did, my ſelfe enforst him to;
Then pardon him ſweete Father for my ſake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vin.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile ſlit the villaines nose that would haue ſent me to the Iaile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: But doe you heare ſir, haue you married my daughter without asking my good will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vin.
SPEECH.LINE: Feare not Baptista, we will content you, goe to: but I will in to be reueng’d for this villanie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap
SPEECH.LINE: And I to ſound the depth of this knauerie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke not pale Bianca, thy father will not frown.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: My cake is dough, but Ile in among the rest,
Out of hope of all, but my ſhare of the feast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Husband let's follow, to ſee the end of this adœ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: First kiſſe me Kate, and we will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: What in the midst of the ſtreete?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: What art thou asham’d of me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſir, God forbid, but asham’d to kiſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then let's home againe: Come Sirra let's awaie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I will giue thee a kiſſe, now praie thee
Loue ſtaie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Is not this well? come my ſweete Kate.
Better once then neuer, for neuer to late.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Baptista, Vincentio, Gremio, the Pedant, Lucentio, and Bianca. Tranio, Biondello Grumio, and Widdow: The Seruingmen with Tranio bringing in a Banquet

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: At last, though long, our iarring notes agree,
And time it is when raging warre is come,
To ſmile at ſcapes and perils ouerblowne:
My faire Bianca bid my father welcome,
While I with ſelfesame kindneſſe welcome thine:
Brother Petruchio, ſister Katerina,
And thou Hortentio with thy louing Widdow:
Feast with the best, and welcome to my house,
My Banket is to close our ſtomakes vp
After our great good cheere: praie you ſit downe,
For now we ſit to chat as well as eate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing but ſit and ſit, and eate and eate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Padua affords this kindneſſe, ſonne Petruchio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Padua affords nothing but what is kinde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: For both our ſakes I would that word were true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Now for my life Hortentio feares his Widow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: Then neuer trust me if I be affeard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: You are verie ſencible, and yet you miſſe my ſence: I meane Hortentio is afeard of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: He that is giddie thinks the world turns round.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Roundlie replied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris, how meane you that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus I conceiue by him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Conceiues by me, how likes Hortentio that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: My Widdow ſaies, thus ſhe conceiues her tale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Verie well mended: kiſſe him for that good
Widdow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: He that is giddie thinkes the world turnes round,
I praie you tell me what you meant by that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: Your housband being troubled with a ſhrew,
Measures my husbands ſorrow by his wœ:
And now you know my meaning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: A verie meane meaning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: Right, I meane you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: And I am meane indeede, respecting you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: To her Kate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: To her Widdow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: That's my office

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Spoke like an Officer: ha to the lad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: How likes Gremio these quicke witted folkes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: Beleeue me ſir, they But together well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: Head, and but an hastie witted bodie,
Would ſay your Head and But were head and horne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vin.
SPEECH.LINE: I Mistris Bride, hath that awakened you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but not frighted me, therefore Ile ſleepe a-gaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay that you ſhall not ſince you haue begun:
Haue at you for a better iest or too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: Am I your Bird, I meane to ſhift my bush,
And then pursue me as you draw your Bow.
You are welcome all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: She hath preuented me, here ſignior Tranio,
This bird you aim’d at, though you hit her not,
Therefore a health to all that ſhot and mist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ſir, Lucentio ſlipt me like his Gray-hound,
Which runs himselfe, and catches for his Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: A good ſwift ſimile, but ſomething currish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis well ſir that you hunted for your ſelfe:
‘Tis thought your Deere does hold you at a baie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, oh Petruchio, Tranio hits you now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke thee for that gird good Tranio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Confeſſe, confeſſe, hath he not hit you here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: A has a little gald me I confeſſe:
And as the Iest did glaunce awaie from me,
‘Tis ten to one it maim’d you too out right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Now in good ſadneſſe ſonne Petruchio,
I thinke thou hast the veriest ſhrew of all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I ſay no: and therefore ſir aſſurance,
Let's each one ſend vnto his wife,
And he whose wife is mo’t obedient,
To come at first when he doth ſend for her,
Shall win the wager which we will propose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hort.
SPEECH.LINE: Content, what’s the wager?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Twentie crownes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Twentie crownes,
Ile venture ſo much of my Hawke or Hound,
But twentie times ſo much vpon my Wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: A hundred then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Content.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: A match, ‘tis done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Who ſhall begin?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: That will I.
Goe Biondello, bid your Mistris come to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bio
SPEECH.LINE: I goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Sonne, Ile be your halfe, Bianca comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile haue no halues: Ile beare it all my ſelfe.
How now, what newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bio.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, my Mistris ſends you word
That ſhe is busie, and ſhe cannot come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: How? ſhe's busie, and ſhe cannot come: is that an answere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gre.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and a kinde one too:
Praie God ſir your wife ſend you not a worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirra Biondello, goe and intreate my wife to come to me forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ho, intreate her, nay then ſhee must needes come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: I am affraid ſir, doe what you can
Yours will not be entreated: Now, where's my wife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bion.
SPEECH.LINE: She ſaies you haue ſome goodly Iest in hand,
She will not come: ſhe bids you come to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Worse and worse, ſhe will not come:
Oh vilde, intollerable, not to be indur’d:
Sirra Grumio, goe to your Mistris,
Say I command her come to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: I know her answere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: What?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: She will not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Now by my hollidam here comes Katerina.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: What is your will ſir, that you ſend for me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is your ſister, and Hortensios wife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſit conferring by the Parler fire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe fetch them hither, if they denie to come,
Swinge me them ſoundly forth vnto their husbands:
Away I ſay, and bring them hither ſtraight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Here is a wonder, if you talke of a wonder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo it is: I wonder what it boads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie peace it boads, and loue, and quiet life,
An awfull rule, and right ſupremicie:
And to be ſhort, what not, that’s ſweete and happie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Now faire befall thee good Petruchio;
The wager thou hast won, and I will adde
Vnto their loſſes twentie thousand crownes,
Another dowrie to another daughter,
For ſhe is chang’d as ſhe had neuer bin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Petr.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I will win my wager better yet,
And ſhow more ſigne of her obedience,
Her new built vertue and obedience.
See where ſhe comes, and brings your froward Wiues
As prisoners to her womanlie perswasion:
Katerine, that Cap of yours becomes you not,
Off with that bable, throw it vnderfoote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord let me neuer haue a cause to ſigh,
Till I be brought to ſuch a ſillie paſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie what a foolish dutie call you this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I would your dutie were as foolish too:
The wisdome of your dutie faire Bianca,
Hath cost me fiue hundred crownes ſince ſupper time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bian.
SPEECH.LINE: The more foole you for laying on my dutie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Katherine I charge thee tell these head-strong women, what dutie they doe owe their Lords and hus-bands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, your mocking: we will haue no telling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on I ſay, and first begin with her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: She ſhall not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay ſhe ſhall, and first begin with her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kate.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, fie, vnknit that threatning vnkinde brow,
And dart not ſcornefull glances from those eies,
To wound thy Lord, thy King, thy Gouernour.
It blots thy beautie, as frosts doe bite the Meads,
Confounds thy fame, as whirlewinds ſhake faire budds,
And in no ſence is meete or amiable.
A woman mou’d, is like a fountaine troubled,
Muddie, ill ſeeming, thicke, bereft of beautie,
And while it is ſo, none ſo dry or thirstie
Will daigne to ſip, or touch one drop of it.
Thy husband is thy Lord, thy life, thy keeper,
Thy head, thy ſoueraigne: One that cares for thee,
And for thy maintenance. Commits his body
To painfull labour, both by ſea and land:
To watch the night in ſtormes, the day in cold,
Whil'st thou ly'st warme at home, ſecure and ſafe,
And craues no other tribute at thy hands,
But loue, faire lookes, and true obedience;
Too little payment for ſo great a debt.
Such dutie as the ſubiect owes the Prince,
Euen ſuch a woman oweth to her husband:
And when ſhe is froward, peeuish, ſullen, ſowre,
And not obedient to his honeſt will,
What is ſhe but a foule contending Rebell,
And graceleſſe Traitor to her louing Lord?
I am asham’d that women are ſo ſimple,
To offer warre, where they ſhould kneele for peace:
Or ſeeke for rule, ſupremacie, and ſway,
When they are bound to ſerue, loue, and obay.
Why are our bodies ſoft, and weake, and ſmooth,
Vnapt to toyle and trouble in the world,
But that our ſoft conditions, and our harts,
Should well agree with our externall parts?
Come, come, you froward and vnable wormes,
My minde hath bin as bigge as one of yours,
My heart as great, my reason haplie more,
To bandie word for word, and frowne for frowne;
But now I ſee our Launces are but ſtrawes:
Our ſtrength as weake, our weakeneſſe past compare,
That ſeeming to be mo’t, which we indeed least are.
Then vale your ſtomackes, for it is no boote,
And place your hands below your husbands foote:
In token of which dutie, if he please,
My hand is readie, may it do him ease.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Why there's a wench: Come on, and kiſſe mee
Kate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Well go thy waies olde Lad for thou ſhalt ha't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vin.
SPEECH.LINE: Tis a good hearing, when children are toward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: But a harsh hearing, when women are froward,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Kate, wee'le to bed,
We three are married, but you two are ſped.
'Twas I wonne the wager, though you hit the white,
And being a winner, God giue you good night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Horten.
SPEECH.LINE: Now goe thy wayes, thou hast tam’d a curst
Shrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Tis a wonder, by your leaue, ſhe wil be tam’d ſo.
